There are many side talks between the employees in the two departments affected by the change. Most of them feel anxiety because there will be changes to their usual way of working, working on new systems which they are not familiar with and changing their work locations. Which of the following models can help them understand what they are feeling and enable them to move through change more efficiently?
explanation: Virginia Satir developed a model of how people experience and cope with change. Its purpose is to help project team members understand what they are feeling and enable them to move through change more efficiently. Domain = Business Environment. PMBOK 7th edition, Page 163

choices.text: OSCAR
Virginia Satir
Cynefin Framework
Herzberg

text: The project team is undergoing an agile transformation. This requires the team members to maintain their original project plans and project documents in the current management tool, but also enter performance data in the new tool built around agile practices. Which of the following documents the project team members will not map into the new agile tool?
explanation: Requirements documentation will be added and maintained by the product owner to the product backlog. It is the product owner's responsibility not the team. Domain = Business Environment. Agile Practice Guide, Page 52

choices.text: Project charter
Team charter
Risk register
Requirements documentation

text: All of the following are among the value delivery office (VDO) roles, except:
explanation: The VDO serves an enabling role, rather than a management or oversight function. It focuses on coaching project teams; building adaptive skills and capabilities throughout the organization; and mentoring sponsors and product owners to be more effective in those roles. Domain = Business Environment. PMBOK 7th edition, Page 141

choices.text: Providing policies, templates and lessons learned for managing projects within the organization.
Mentoring sponsors and product owners to be more effective in those roles.
Coaching project teams.
Building adaptive skills and capabilities throughout the organization.

text: A large project is being implemented within an organization which entails large organizations changes. Employees in the organization feel confusion, anxiety and frustration. Which of the following models can be used to deal with them psychologically?
explanation: Transition Model provides an understanding of what occurs to individuals psychologically when an organizational change takes place. This model differentiates between change and transition. Change is situational and happens whether or not people transition through it. Transition is a psychological process where people gradually accept the details of the new situation and the changes that come with it. Domain = Business Environment. PMBOK 7th edition, Page 164

choices.text: ADKAR
Virginia Satir
The 8-Step Process for Leading Change
Transition Model

text: You are managing a project to develop a new pharmaceutical compound. The project is very difficult and has a tight schedule. A quality auditor came to you to perform a quality audit on your project. Your team is already under pressure to complete the project. They object to the audit due to the work pressure. You should explain to the team that the purpose of a quality audit is:
explanation: The project manager is not authorized to check if the customer is following the quality process. Inspecting the deliverables and prevent defect ones to go to the customer is the focus of Control Quality process. The quality audits are tools of the Perform Quality Assurance process which focus on following processes and procedures. Although ISO 9000 is a quality standard, but it is not the main focus of quality audits. So the best answer is to identify inefficient and ineffective policies. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 294

choices.text: To check if the customer is following the quality process.
To inspect deliverables and prevent defective ones to go to the customer.
To satisfy part of an ISO 9000 investigation.
To identify inefficient and ineffective policies.

text: During the execution of your new product development project, a new quality standard is issued and your project team is holding a meeting with the quality department to determine how the standard will apply to the running project. This is part of which quality management process?
explanation: Team is defining how to meet the new standard, it is part of the Plan Quality Management process. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 277

choices.text: Plan Quality Management
Manage Quality
Total Quality Management
Control Quality

text: Catherine is closing her first project, she is collecting lessons learned with project team members and stakeholders. Many stakeholders were not satisfied about the project and they complained that their needs were not fully met. Her boss asks her about the steps she took on her project to improve customer satisfaction. Which subsidiary plan would she consult to determine this information?
explanation: The quality management plan is a component of the project management plan that describes how applicable policies, procedures, and guidelines will be implemented to achieve the quality objectives. It describes the activities and resources necessary for the project management team to achieve the quality objectives set for the project. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 286 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 186

choices.text: Quality Management Plan
Scope Management Plan
Stakeholders Management Plan
Risk Management Plan

text: A project manager of a manufacturing project is analyzing activities that doesn’t add value to the project and wastes company resources and time. A team member informed him that a process is not understood and another one informed him that two processes he works on, he thinks they are not needed. The project manager must be leading which of the following?
explanation: Manage Quality process is concerned with following and improving processes and increasing its efficiency. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 290

choices.text: Manage Quality
Control Quality
A process rather than a project
Plan Quality Management

text: Samuel is managing a project to develop a new pharmaceutical compound. He noticed that the packing process has many problems, so he held a meeting with his team to examine problems and non-value-added activities that occur during packing process. They also identified many opportunities to improve the process. Which process are they involved in and which tool are they using?
explanation: Process analysis identifies opportunities for process improvements. This analysis also examines problems, constraints, and non-value-added activities that occur during a process.

choices.text: Plan Quality Management, mind mapping
Control Quality, performance reviews
Control Quality, product evaluation
Manage Quality, process analysis

text: Luke is a project manager in a construction company. He was assigned to manage a construction project to build a new shopping center. During performing the strength tests, he found severe failure in the strength tests. He assigned Steve to investigate this problem. Steve started tracking the problem to determine and solve the main reasons behind it. Which tool should Steve use to track the problem?
explanation: Cause-and-effect (Fishbone) diagrams are used to trace the problem's source back to its root cause. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 293

choices.text: Fishbone diagram
Histogram
Design of experiments
Design for X

text: A new medicine has been released in market by a large pharmaceutical company. A serious side effect has been discovered which may cause a sudden decrease in blood pressure. The company has recalled all products from the market. The incurred cost for recalling the medicine is known as:
explanation: Cost of failures found by the customer is considered a cost of non conformance. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 283 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 88

choices.text: Cost of conformance
Cost of non conformance
Cost of prevention
Cost of inspection

text: Catherine is a project manager for a new product development project. After the product of the project has been released, it was found to have numerous features more than any other similar product in the market, but obvious defects have been found by the users of the product. The product is categorized as:
explanation: The high-grade product has numerous features and the low quality product has many defects. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 274

choices.text: High grade, low quality
Low grade, low quality
Low grade, high quality
High grade, high quality

text: Smith is managing a large product development project. The customer of the project has very tight quality tolerance and will not accept any defected product. He has set strict quality control measures and feedback verification loops from a similar previous project. However during scope validation, the customer has rejected a high percentage of the products due to defects found. Which of the following is the best course of action?
explanation: It is clear that in this situation the quality control procedures including verification and feedback loops were taken from a similar project without tailoring. Quality control procedures and quality assurance steps need to be tailored for the specific needs for this project. Domain = Process. PMBOK 7th edition, Page 151

choices.text: Escalate this topic to the steering committee.
More tailoring for quality control procedures and quality assurance steps.
Demonstrate the quality control measures and feedback verification loops to the customer.
Review the customer's inspection process.

text: The project team is in the design phase of a new car prototype. The team is analyzing which type of motors and wheels would provide a high speed with more safety. Which of the following is the most likely technique would they use to determine these variables?
explanation: Design of experiments helps to determine a group of variables to improve quality. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 290

choices.text: Matrix diagrams
Cost-benefit analysis
Design for X
Design of experiments

text: You are a project manager for a new construction project. Your project is to build a new housing compound which contains 10,000 houses. The houses are substantially similar. What must you do?
explanation: If the project has some repeated activities, the lessons learned of the first few installations can be used to improve the process on the remaining installations. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 289

choices.text: Plan in continuous improvement activities.
Make sure the first and last of these work packages is scheduled close in time to each other.
See what can be done to remove the similarity.
Make sure the same resource completes all the similar work packages.

text: While testing the stability of the electronic board used in your project, you discover that it becomes unstable when it works in high temperature which doesn’t meet your company’s quality standards. You are sure that it will function as it is with the customer, and you don’t think the board needs to meet the quality level specified. What should you do?
explanation: Stating in your reports that the board simply “meets our quality needs” or changing the quality standards to meet the achieved level are against the professional and social responsibility of the project manager. Documenting the problem in lessons learned register maybe done later because it doesn't solve the current problem. So the best solution is to report the lesser quality and try to find a solution. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 299

choices.text: State in your reports that the board simply “meets our quality needs”.
Change the quality standards to meet the achieved level.
Document this problem in lessons learned register and send this board to customer.
Report the lesser quality and try to find a solution.

text: You are in the middle of executing a major new construction project. The project is very important and highly visible in your organization. The sponsor informed you that he is worried that the project will not meet the quality standards it was intended to. If the project doesn't meet the quality standard, the customer will not be satisfied. What should you do in this situation?
explanation: Assuring the sponsor that the project would meet the quality standards is not a solution. Historical information of your past projects don't indicate the status of the current project. The Quality Management Plan doesn't indicate the current situation. Forming a quality assurance team will indicate if the team is following the correct processes and procedures which meets the quality standards and metrics. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 294

choices.text: Assure the sponsor that during the Plan Quality Management process, it was determined that the project would meet the quality standards.
Form a quality assurance team.
Show him the historical information of your past projects that they all met the quality standards.
Check the results from the last quality management plan.

text: Adam is managing an industrial project when one of the project team members informed him that the dimensions of one of the project deliverables are different than the planned dimensions and thus it will be unable to operate with the machine. Adam asked the team member to determine the basic underlying reasons that cause this variance and also to determine whether these reasons might cause other variances in other project deliverables. Which tool should the team member use in this situation?
explanation: Root cause analysis is an analytical technique used to determine the basic underlying reason that causes a variance, defect, or risk. A root cause may underlie more than one variance, defect, or risk. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 292 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 177

choices.text: Audits
Alternatives analysis
Root cause analysis (RCA)
Process analysis

text: Project changes are approved during the _____  process and verified during the______ process.
explanation: Project changes are approved during the Perform Integrated Change Control process and verified during the Control Quality process. Domain = Process PMBOK 6th edition, Page 301

choices.text: Perform Integrated Change Control, Control Quality.
Perform Integrated Change Control, Validate Scope.
Perform Integrated Change Control, Control Scope.
Monitor and Control Project Work, Validate Scope..

text: During planning your project, you are balancing project constraints scope, time, cost, quality,..The customer required that quality of this project must be as high as possible. This type of projects is relatively new to your organization. What is the best thing to do in this situation?
explanation: Benchmarking is not effective here because this type of projects is new. Using Ishikawa diagram or control charts are not proactive solutions. So the best answer is to audit work as it is being completed to look for any needed improvements. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 294

choices.text: Audit work as it is being completed to look for any needed improvements.
Use Ishikawa diagram when there is a defect.
Benchmark the current project quality standards to identify best practices.
Use control charts to make sure that the process is in control.

text: Alex is a project manager working for automobile manufacturer for a project to build more fuel-efficient, high stability small cars. He and his team determine how to inspect the product of the project to meet the stakeholders’ needs and expectations, as well as to meet the goal for the product’s performance and reliability. In which process are they involved and which tool are they using?
explanation: During the planning phase in the Plan Quality Management process, the project manager and the project team determine how to test or inspect the product, deliverable, or service to meet the stakeholders’ needs and expectations, as well as how to meet the goal for the product’s performance and reliability. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 285

choices.text: Manage Quality, Process Analysis
Manage Quality, Audits
Control Quality, Inspection
Plan Quality Management, Test and inspection planning

text: While analyzing the last year performance of the company, it was found that the company has lost many customers especially who used the products of the company during last year. The CEO informed all the project managers to pay more attention to quality management. He focused not just on giving customers products without any defects by keeping the defective ones out of the customer hands, but keeping errors out of the process of producing deliverables. Keeping errors out of the process is known as:
explanation: Prevention means keeping errors out of the process and inspection means keeping errors out of the hands of the customer. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 274

choices.text: Variable sampling
Attribute sampling
Prevention
Inspection

text: Thomas is managing a large project to produce a new pharmaceutical drug. The project is very important for his company and quality has a top priority. Strict quality standards have been put in place and they must be followed. In order to achieve the required quality standard, Thomas approved on a business trip for two team members to have training on the new quality standards. The cost of team members training is an example of:
explanation: Prevention costs are costs related to the prevention of poor quality in the products, deliverables, or services of the specific project. Examples on prevention costs are training and equipment. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 282 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 88

choices.text: Failure costs
Cost of nonconformance
Appraisal cost
Prevention cost

text: A project team adopts extreme programming method (XP) is working on a software project. XP applies the concept of pair programming where the team members are writing software code together as a pair and reviewing each other's work to determine if the code conforms to the requirements documentation or not. What will be a result of these reviews?
explanation: A goal of the Control Quality process is to determine the correctness of deliverables. The results of performing the Control Quality process are verified deliverables that become an input to the Validate Scope process for formalized acceptance. As the two developers inspect each other completed work, so they are doing the same as Control Quality process. Domain = Process. Agile Practice Guide, Page 102 and PMBOK 6th edition, Page 305

choices.text: Product Increment
Minimum Viable Product
Accepted Deliverables
Verified deliverable

text: A new cell phone has been released in markets as a product of a project in a multi-national organization. It seems that some defects have been noticed by customers in the new cell phone. The organization decided to make a survey in all shops to collect data about the defects. The cost regarding defects identified in the surveys may be considered as:
explanation: The cost regarding defects identified in the surveys may be considered external failure costs in the COQ model and can have extensive cost implications for the organization. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 303 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 88

choices.text: Prevention costs
Appraisal costs
Internal failure costs
External failure costs

text: Which of the following statements indicates the optimal cost of quality?
explanation: The optimal COQ is one that reflects the appropriate balance for investing in the cost of prevention and appraisal to avoid failure costs. So costs of conformance should be less than costs of nonconformance. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 282 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 88

choices.text: Appraisal costs should be less than prevention costs.
Costs of conformance should be less than costs of nonconformance.
Prevention costs should be more than external failure costs.
Internal failure costs should be less than prevention costs.

text: Carol is an experienced project manager in her organization. She is managing an IT project using agile approach. A team member asks Carol about the quality control activities when and by whom they will be performed. Which of the following would be her answer?
explanation: In agile projects, the Control Quality activities may be performed by all team members throughout the project life cycle. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 75

choices.text: The Control Quality activities may be performed by all team members towards the end of the project or phase.
The Control Quality activities may be performed by Quality Control team throughout the project life cycle.
The Control Quality activities may be performed by all team members throughout the project life cycle.
The Control Quality activities may be performed by Quality Control team towards the end of the project or phase.

text: Costs of testing and inspections are examples of:
explanation: Appraisal costs are costs related to evaluating, measuring, auditing, and testing the products, deliverables, or services of the specific project like testing and inspection. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 283 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 88

choices.text: Failure costs
Cost of nonconformance
Appraisal cost
Prevention cost

text: William is a project manager in a chemicals industrial company. The PMO in this company has authorized William to manage a project to lessen environmental impacts of one of its products. He found that replacing one type of material used in the product with another new environment friendly material, will decrease environmental impacts. He and his team are studying the consequences of removing the material and using the new material on the product technical properties like quality and price. Which technique should help the team in this situation?
explanation: A scatter diagram is a graph that shows the relationship between two variables. Scatter diagrams can demonstrate a relationship between any element of a process, environment, or activity on one axis and a quality defect on the other axis. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 293 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 189

choices.text: Matrix diagrams
Cause- and- effect diagram
Scatter diagram
Histogram

text: A project manager for a new electronic chips manufacturing project needs to make sure that the deliverables meet the quality standards. The project team produces about 100,000 chips per day, so testing all the deliverables would take much time and cost. The chips are so small that inspection would destroy them. Under these circumstances, what should the project manager do?
explanation: You need to take a valid sample of the products of the project if inspecting the entire population would take much time, or if inspecting the products would be destructive. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 303

choices.text: Inspect a sample of the deliverables.
Outsource the inspection to another company with more expertise.
Test all the deliverables to meet the quality standard.
Form a quality assurance team to audit the manufacturing process.

text: Testing the stability of one of the electronic chips manufactured by your company to determine if it meets your quality standards is an example of:
explanation: Statistical sampling involves choosing part of a population of interest for inspection. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 303

choices.text: Benchmarking
Design of experiments
Statistical sampling
Design for X

text: Andrew is a project manager in an industrial firm. He is taking over a manufacturing project from another project manager who resigned two weeks ago. Previously the company has faced criticism for the project deliverables from the customer. The previous project manager didn't pay much attention to quality of deliverables. Andrew hired inspectors to inspect the product of the project and prevent the defective ones from reaching the customer. He required from the extra inspectors to record the inspection results of the products as either conform or do not conform to quality requirements. This technique is known as:
explanation: Attribute sampling means that the result either conforms or does not conform and variable sampling means that the result is rated on a continuous scale that measures the degree of conformity. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 274

choices.text: Variable sampling
Attribute sampling
Prevention
Statistical sampling

text: Luis is a project manager in an electronics firm. He has been assigned to manage a new project to develop a faster, cheaper, and smaller laptop. He is analyzing the defects found in the product by graphical representation of this numerical data. The graph shows the ranking of the cause of defects and the number of defects found per deliverable. Which data representation technique is he using?
explanation: Histograms show a graphical representation of numerical data. Histograms can show the number of defects per deliverable, a ranking of the cause of defects, the number of times each process is noncompliant, or other representations of project or product defects. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 293

choices.text: Histogram
Scatter Diagram
Matrix diagram
Cause-and-effect diagram

text: A project manager is executing a construction project. He is working with the quality assurance team to ensure that the project will satisfy the quality standards and metrics. Which of the following must they have before they start this process?
explanation: Quality control measurements are used to analyze and evaluate the quality of the processes and deliverables of the project against the standards of the performing organization or the requirements specified. Quality control measurements can also compare the processes used to create the measurements and validate actual measurements to determine their level of correctness. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 288

choices.text: Quality control measurements
Quality assurance plan
Verified deliverables
Quality reports

text: A project manager for a product development project was informed by a team member that a defect was found in a deliverable that must be delivered to customer tomorrow according to the project schedule. The project manager knows that the customer doesn’t have the technical understanding to notice the defect. The deliverable meets the contract requirements, but it doesn’t meet the project manager’s quality standard. What is the best course of action for the project manager?
explanation: Issuing the deliverable although it doesn't meet quality requirements is against the professional and social responsibility of a project manager. Documenting the problem in lessons learned register is a good solution for future projects, but it doesn't solve the current situation. Informing the customer that the deliverable will be late may breach the contract and harm the relationship, so the best option is to discuss the issue with the customer. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 299

choices.text: Issue the deliverable and get formal acceptance from the customer, as the deliverable meets his quality standard.
Inform the customer that the deliverable will be late and fix the fault.
Discuss the issue with the customer.
Note the problem in the lessons learned register so future projects do not face the same problem.

text: Chris is managing a product development project. He receives a call from a team member informing him that they have found the same defect which has been identified before during a previous inspection. Chris is confused how this could have happened. He has raised a change request before to repair this defect and the change was approved. After investigation, he learns that the team did not implement the approved change. This situation indicates a gap in which process?
explanation: A part of the Control Quality process is to review approved changes. Approved change requests may include modifications such as defect repairs, revised work methods, and revised schedules. The implementation of approved changes should be verified, confirmed for completeness, retested, and certified as correct. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 301

choices.text: Plan Quality Management
Control Scope
Control Quality
Perform Integrated Change Control

text: Which of the following statements best describes the difference between Validate Scope and Control Quality?
explanation: Validate Scope is concerned with the acceptance of deliverables while the Control Quality is concerned with correctness of the deliverables. Verified deliverables is an output of the Control Quality process and input to the Validate Scope process. Generally Control Quality is performed before the Validate Scope process. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 164

choices.text: Validate Scope is generally performed before Control Quality.
Validate Scope is concerned with the acceptance of deliverables while the Control Quality is concerned with correctness of the deliverables.
Verified deliverables are outputs of the Validate Scope process and input to the Control Quality process.
Accepted deliverables are outputs of the Control Quality process and input to the Validate Scope process.

text: During a retrospective, a stakeholder expressed his concerns about the quality of the product increments delivered so far. The stakeholder has mentioned that the team is not able to deliver high-quality product increment. Which of the following is the best course of action?
explanation: The best answer is that the project leader and the team need to further discuss the quality related topics first and review the quality processes. If further assistance is needed they can involve the functional manager. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 299 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 87

choices.text: Involve the quality manager to investigate the project quality processes.
Arrange training sessions for the team members to improve the quality of the product increments.
Assign more quality subject matter experts to the project to improve quality processes.
The project leader should discuss this topic with the team and review the quality processes.

text: The project team has found that the team velocity has dropped significantly and they have a critical deliverable due in two weeks. The team members decide to skip final test in order to bring the project back on track and don't miss the deliverable due date. Which of the following is a likely result of the team decision?
explanation: Removing a test will lead to technical debt which means degraded deliverables quality. Domain = Process. Agile Practice Guide, Page 58

choices.text: Increased technical debt
Increased customer satisfaction
Increased return on investment
Increased resources cost

text: You are managing a new construction project that is budgeted at $3,000,000. Too many activities are being executed underway on your project. You are getting worried about the accuracy of the progress reporting your team members are doing. How could you verify whether there is a problem or not?
explanation: Perform a quality audit as part of the Manage Quality process to verify that there is a problem or not. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 294 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 87

choices.text: Feasibility studies
Quality audits
Sensitivity analysis
Monte Carlo Analysis

text: Barbara is managing a large industrial project. Recently, her company received many complaints due to defects found by the customer in the first deliverable. The customer is not satisfied at all with the first project deliverable. The project sponsor is very angry and told her that the company may lose the contract with the customer if they find defects in the next deliverables. In order to reduce sponsor's stress, she told him that they will compare the product’s quality standards to those of another comparable successful products to identify best practices and increase the probability of customer acceptance. Which tool is she using?
explanation: Benchmarking is the comparison of actual or planned practices of your project to those of other projects to identify best practices and improve performance. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 284

choices.text: Matrix diagrams
Logical data model
Benchmarking
Mind mapping

text: Bill is managing an industrial project. He requested from his team to organize potential causes of quality problems into groups to know which causes they should focus on. Which tool should the team use in this situation?
explanation: Affinity diagrams can organize potential causes of defects into groups showing areas that should be focused on the most. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 293 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 178

choices.text: Control Charts
Scatter diagrams
Affinity diagrams
Why-why diagram

text: A project manager for a hardware design project and his team are using cause and effect diagram, trying to determine how various factors might have contributed to project problems. The project manager is involved in which part of the quality management process?
explanation: The key word here is (might have contributed) this means that the problem already happened, so they are involved in the Control Quality process. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 304

choices.text: Total Quality Management
Control Quality
Manage Quality
Plan Quality Management

text: You are a project manager for an industrial project. Your project is being audited by the company’s quality assurance department. They have found that your team has implemented the process inefficiently, which lead to defects in your product. What’s the next thing that should happen on your project?
explanation: They are now involved in the Manage Quality process. One of the outputs of this process is Change Request. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 296

choices.text: Add the problem to the risk register and develop a response plan.
Suggest corrective actions and submit them to the change control board.
Add the results of the audit to the lessons learned.
You meet with the manager of the quality assurance department to find a solution of the problem.

text: Project deliverables are produced during the ______ process, verified during the ______ process and formally accepted during the ______ process.
explanation: Project deliverables are produced during the Direct and manage project work process, verified during the Control Quality process and formally accepted during the Validate Scope process. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 299 and 305

choices.text: Perform Integrated Change Control, Control Quality, Validate Scope
Direct and manage project work, Validate Scope, Control Quality
Direct and Manage Project Work, Control Quality, Control Scope
Direct and manage project work, Control Quality, Validate Scope

text: All of the following are examples of cost of quality except:
explanation: The cost of quality is the cost incurred to prevent, discover or repair a defect. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 283 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 88

choices.text: Having team members spend extra time reviewing requirements with the stakeholders.
Paying extra labor to help meet a deadline.
Hiring extra inspectors to look for defects.
Sending a technician to repair a defective product that was delivered to the client.

text: David is managing a software project. He wants to find the strength of relationships among different factors. He asked John a more experienced project manager, John told him there is a tool that can give him information about the relationship, such as its strength, the roles played by various individuals or measurements. What is the tool which John refers to?
explanation: Matrix diagrams help find the strength of relationships among different factors, causes, and objectives that exist between the rows and columns that form the matrix. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 284

choices.text: Matrix diagrams
Logical data model
Flowcharts
Mind mapping

text: Quality audits should be
explanation: Quality audits may be scheduled or random, and may be conducted by internal or external auditors Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 295

choices.text: Scheduled with external auditors
Random with internal auditors
Scheduled or random with internal or external auditors
Scheduled with internal auditors

text: Physical resource management is concentrated in all of the following except:
explanation: Identifying roles and responsibilities of team members clearly without ambiguity is parts of managing human resources not physical resources. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 310 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 65

choices.text: Keeping enough inventory.
Allocating and using equipments.
Identifying roles and responsibilities of team members clearly without ambiguity.
Securing critical equipment and material on time.

text: If your organization is using Kaizen and and Just-In-Time (JIT) methods, you must take them into consideration when you manage your projects because they will mostly affect on:
explanation: Due to the scarce nature of critical resources, in some industries, several trends have become popular in the past several years. There is extensive literature about lean management, just-in-time (JIT) manufacturing, Kaizen, total productive maintenance (TPM), Theory of constraints (TOC), and other methods. A Project Manager should determine if the performing organisation has adopted one or more resource management tools and adapt to the project accordingly. Domain = process. PMBOK 6th edition, page 310.

choices.text: Resource Management
Procurement Management
Communication Management
Scope Management

text: You are the project manager for a software project. The project sponsor has asked you for a forecast for the cost of project completion. Which of the following is the best metric to use for forecasting?
explanation: Only ETC & VAC look forward (forecast), while CPI, SPI, SV, CV, EV & AC look backward. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 265 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 104

choices.text: EV and AC
SV and CV
ETC and VAC
SPI and CPI

text: Which of the following statements is true regarding project resources management?
explanation: Project resources management is concerned with managing physical and human resources. There is some overlap between Project Resource Management and Project Stakeholder Management. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 309 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 186

choices.text: Project resources management is concerned with managing physical resources, while project stakeholders management is concerned with managing human resources.
Project resources management is concerned with managing human resources, while project scope management is concerned with managing physical resources.
Project resource management is concerned with managing human resources only.
Project resources management is concerned with managing physical and human resources.

text: A project is being implemented using an adaptive approach. During a meeting with the customer, he requested to add a new requirement to the next iteration which might need other resources outside the project team. The needed resources are available within the organization. The project team wants to ensure resources availability to perform the new requirement, however there is a risk that the customer may cancel or postpone the new requirement before the next iteration starts. What should the project team do?
explanation: Soft booking is the term for the process of scheduling resources in a project that haven't been confirmed yet. If the resource or service hasn't yet been confirmed, you have to make assumptions about when they'll be available and what their costs will be. Domain = Process.

choices.text: Inform the customer that they will assign the needed resources and he will pay their fees in case of cancellation.
Use soft booking for the needed resources.
Don't hire the needed resources unless there is a written confirmation from the customer for the new requirement.
Assign two team members to learn the needed skills to perform the new requirements.

text: A RACI chart is an example of:
explanation: A RACI is a detailed responsibility assignment matrix. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 317 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 189

choices.text: Hierarchical-type organization chart
Text-oriented position description
Responsibility assignment matrix
Control Charts

text: Mark is managing a large software project. The project is very large, it consists of 75 team members and is planned to take two years. At the end of each quarter, he performs an assessment for each team member to know the areas of strengths and weaknesses for each one. Which process is he involved in?
explanation: Individual and team assessment tools give the project manager and the project team insight into areas of strengths and weaknesses. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 342

choices.text: Manage Team
Acquire Resources
Develop Team
Control Resources

text: Which of the following statements best describes the team charter?
explanation: The team charter is a document that establishes the team values, agreements, and operating guidelines for the team. Domain = Process. PMBOK 7th edition, Page 192

choices.text: The team charter is a document that contains the project objectives, high level project plan and success criteria.
The team charter is a document that contains the KPI's and appraisals of the project team members.
The team charter is a document that establishes the team values, agreements, and operating guidelines for the team.
The team charter is a document that contains the roles and responsibilities of the project team members.

text: An agile team is involved in a network installation project using scrum methodology. A network migration activity must be done during downtime and a team member must be assigned to this task. None of the team members wants to sign up for this task. How should this situation be addressed?
explanation: Task assignments are done by the team as the team is self-managed and self-organized. Domain = Process. Agile Practice Guide Page 44

choices.text: The senior most team member should be assigned to this task.
The scrum master should try first to reschedule the activity to daytime.
The scrum master should decide who will pick up this task.
The team should decide who will pick up this task.

text: Which of the following describes the contents of a resources management plan?
explanation: Conflict resolution techniques, personnel performance appraisal and team performance assessment are not included in the resources management plan. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 318

choices.text: Guidance on how to acquire team and physical resources, project organization charts, conflict resolution techniques and release plan.
Competence, roles, personnel performance appraisal and recognition and rewards.
Identification of resources, release plan, staff training needs, and team performance assessment.
Authority, Training Needs, Recognition and Rewards, and Release Plan.

text: George is responsible for managing the spare parts in a large tele-communication project. He monitors the spare parts usage in a timely manner. He always informs the project manager if any spare part has shortage or surplus and takes the needed actions to adjust spare parts usage. Which process is he involved in?
explanation: Control Resources is concerned with identifying and dealing with resource shortage/surplus in a timely manner. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 354

choices.text: Monitor Risks
Acquire Resources
Control Resources
Control Scope

text: What is the focus of the Control Resources process?
explanation: Control Resources is the process of ensuring that the physical resources assigned and allocated to the project are available as planned, as well as monitoring the planned versus actual utilization of resources and taking corrective action as necessary. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 352

choices.text: Ensuring that the physical resources assigned and allocated to the project are available as planned.
Ensuring that the physical and human resources assigned and allocated to the project are available as planned.
Ensuring that the physical, human and monetary resources assigned and allocated to the project are available as planned.
Ensuring that the human resources assigned and allocated to the project are available as planned.

text: All of the following statements about Control Resources process is true, except:
explanation: The resources needed for the project should be assigned and released at the right time not as early as possible, right place, and right amount for the project to continue without delays. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 353

choices.text: Control Resources process should be performed continuously in all project phases and throughout the project life cycle.
The resources needed for the project should be assigned and released as early as possible, at the right place, and right amount for the project to continue without delays.
The Control Resources process is concerned with physical resources only.
The Control Resources process is not concerned with project human resources.

text: You are a project manager for a complex software project. You need to assign a web developer to your project to perform some complex activities. The needed developer should have great experience to perform the needed activities. You asked the resource manager to assign Steve, who is known that he is an excellent web developer in the organization and he has great experience. The resource manager rejected because Steve is assigned full time to another higher priority project in the organization. You have a conflict with the resource manager because assigning any other developer to perform these activities has great risk to your project, because all other developers within the organization have little experience. Which process are you involved in?
explanation: You are involved in the Acquire Resources process, because the project manager here negotiates with the resource manager to provide the required resources for the project. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 330

choices.text: Manage Team
Acquire Resources
Estimate Activity Resources
Control Resources

text: Your team has made great achievements during your project, and you want to reward them for their great performance. Which of the following contains the bonus plan for your project?
explanation: The Resources Management plan includes a “Reward and Recognition” section that describes how you’ll reward your team for good performance Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 319 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 186

choices.text: Resource Breakdown Structure
The resources management plan
The resource histogram
The resource calendars

text: Matt is a project manager for a large tele-communication project. He and his team are now determining the types, quantities and skills of the needed resources for each project activity. They will need to store their spare parts in a warehouse as it will be needed for all the project duration. They are now evaluating whether to buy a warehouse and hire employees to manage it or to outsource the warehousing activities to another company. Which process are they involved in and which tool are they using?
explanation: As they are determining the types, quantities and skills of the needed resources, so they are involved in the Estimate Activity Resources. As they are evaluating identified options in order to select the options or approaches to use to execute and perform the work of the project, so they are using alternatives analysis which is an example of data analysis. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition Page 325

choices.text: Estimate Activity Resources and Data Analysis
Plan Resources Management and Data Representation
Acquire Resources and Decision Making
Estimate Activity Resources and Analogous Estimating

text: Which of the following are included in the responsibility assignment matrix (RAM)?
explanation: A responsibility assignment matrix (RAM) is a grid that shows the project resources assigned to each activity or work package. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 317 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 189

choices.text: Activity and resource
Resource and time estimate
Activity and attributes
Activity and calendar date

text: Resource management plan is concerned with planning for all the following resources except:
explanation: Monetary resources is addressed through the Estimate Costs process. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 313 and 240

choices.text: Facilities
Monetary resources
Team members
Supplies

text: Paul is managing an industrial project. In the middle of the project, a project team member noticed that there is a sudden increase in the usage of fuel in a machine. The machine normally consumes 3 litres per day, and its consumption became 5 litres per day with the same level of effort. The team member informed Paul about the problem. In order to control the usage of fuel, Paul asked the team member to cooperate with the technical support team to investigate the problem. They found a defect in a component in the machine which caused the abnormal usage when it is fixed the machine worked normally with the original consumption rate. Which process are they involved in?
explanation: Control Resources is concerned with influencing the factors that can create resources utilization change. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 354

choices.text: Control Resources
Control Quality
Manage Quality
Control Scope

text: Gary is a project manager for a large mechanical project. He is documenting the roles, responsibilities, required skills and reporting relationships for the needed resources. Where should he document this information?
explanation: Roles, responsibilities, required skills and reporting relationships for the needed resources are documented in the resources management plan. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 318 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 186

choices.text: Resource Requirements
RACI chart
Responsibility Assignment Matrix
Resources Management Plan

text: Which of the following statements is true regarding acquiring project resources?
explanation: The resources needed for the project can be internal or external to the project-performing organization. Internal resources are acquired (assigned) from functional or resource managers. External resources are acquired through the procurement processes. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 329 and PMBOK Guide 7th edition, Page 65

choices.text: Internal resources are acquired from functional or resource managers. External resources are acquired through the procurement processes.
Internal resources are acquired through procurement processes. External resources are acquired from functional or resource managers.
Internal resources are acquired from functional or resource managers. External resources are acquired through the procurement processes.
Internal and external resources are acquired from functional or resource managers.

text: Which of the following statements is true?
explanation: The Control Resources process is concerned with physical resources such as equipment, materials, facilities, and infrastructure. Team members are addressed in the Manage Team process. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 353

choices.text: The Control Resources process is concerned with controlling physical resources only, while Manage Team is concerned with managing all resources.
The Control Resources process is concerned with controlling all resources, while Manage Team is concerned with managing all resources.
The Control Resources process is concerned with controlling physical resources only, while Manage Team is concerned with managing team members.
The Control Resources process is concerned with controlling all resources, while Manage Team is concerned with managing team members.

text: During developing the risk management plan for your project, you need to determine the acceptable level of the overall project risk exposure for your project. What should you do first?
explanation: Stakeholder risk appetite should be expressed as measurable risk thresholds around each project objective. These thresholds will determine the acceptable level of overall project risk exposure. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 398 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 122

choices.text: It can be determined from the historical information for a similar project.
It can be determined after performing quantitative analysis for the identified project risks.
It can be determined after planning for risk responses.
Determine the risk appetite for key stakeholders.

text: Alberto is managing a large industrial project that is budgeted at 9,000,000$ and scheduled to be completed in 9 months. After 5 months during project executing, he reviews a weekly work performance report from his team. He planned with his team a contingency plan with a predetermined risk trigger for a cost performance index CPI of 0.9. He finds that the earned value measurements are PV = 5,500,000$, EV = 4,850,000$ and AC = 5,250,000$. What should he do first?
explanation: The risk trigger here is when CPI reaches value of 0.9. and here CPI = EV/AC = 0.92 which means that the trigger is not reached. So the risk didn't occur to implement the contingency plan. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 450

choices.text: Look for ways to bring the project back on track.
Determine the root cause of low cost performance index.
Implement the contingency plan.
Nothing, because the CPI indicates that the trigger is not reached.

text: The project manager is holding a risk reassessment meeting with the project team and the project sponsor, the sponsor is looking at the latest list of top risks in the project report. A new risk has been identified and assessed. That risk ranking was lower than all of the previously identified risks. Three fallback plans have been adjusted based on the severity of previous risk impacts. Which of the following has the project manager forgotten to do?
explanation: It is not the responsibility of the project sponsor to review a full list of non-critical risks but he may review residual risks. There is nothing called contingency risks. Quantitative risk analysis is not performed to risks which rank lower than all of the previously identified risks. Quantitative risk analysis is performed for top risks only. The best answer here is to look at the impact of the new risk to the project as a whole as a part of the Identify Risks process. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 411 and PMBOK 7th edition Page 123

choices.text: Look at the impact of the new risk to the project as a whole.
Provide the sponsor with the full list of non-critical risks.
Look for contingency risks from the fallback plan.
Perform quantitative risk analysis for the new risk.

text: Alexander is a project manager for a major software project. He is interviewing the members of a project team to test their understanding of the assigned risk responses as risk owners. He is working with the risk management department in the organization to evaluate the risk responses to determine their effectiveness in the project. What project management technique is he performing?
explanation: Risk audits examine and document the effectiveness of risk responses in dealing with identified risks and their root causes, as well as the effectiveness of the risk management process. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 456

choices.text: Risk responses implementation
Risk response planning
Risk audit
Risk reassessment

text: Mark is a project manager for a tele-communications project in his organization. Tom is his sponsor and he is working with David, the risk manager in the organization to determine the effectiveness of the risk responses. Tom and David are concerned that some of the risks assigned to Frederick, a project team member to implement the planned risk responses may not be addressed to the depth they would like. In this scenario, what are they doing?
explanation: Risk audits examine and document the effectiveness of risk responses in dealing with identified risks and their root causes, as well as the effectiveness of the risk management process. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 456

choices.text: Risk Audit
Risk Reassessment
Risk Review
Variance Analysis

text: A project manager on an industrial project decided to insure against fire. This is an example of:
explanation: Insurance means transference of risk. Domain = Process. PMBOK 7th edition, Page 123

choices.text: Transference
Mitigation
Avoidance
Escalation

text: You are managing a project to design a high-efficiency solar cell using a predictive development approach. Midway through the project, several issues have occurred and now the project schedule and budget are in jeopardy. What is the best course of action to address these issues?
explanation: Management reserves are withheld for unforeseen risks that affect the project. According to the scenario, the issues developed during the project were unexpected. All other actions can be performed later in the project. Adding an entry in the issue log will not address those issues. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 254 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 62

choices.text: Add an entry in the issue log.
Use management reserve.
Re-evaluate the identify risks process.
Repeat the identify risks process.

text: Which of the following charts can be used to represent risks by their impact, probability and proximity?
explanation: Where risks have been categorized using more than two parameters, the probability and impact matrix cannot be used and other graphical representations are required. For example, a bubble chart displays three dimensions of data, where each risk is plotted as a disk (bubble), and the three parameters are represented by the x-axis value, the y-axis value, and the bubble size. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 425

choices.text: Probability and impact matrix
Risk Breakdown Structure
Bubble Chart
Cause and effect diagram

text: Which of the following indicates what is meant by risk propinquity?
explanation: Propinquity is the degree to which a risk is perceived to matter by one or more stakeholders. Where a risk is perceived as very significant, propinquity is high. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 424

choices.text: The degree to which a risk is perceived to matter by one or more stakeholders.
The extent to which the risk is related to other individual project risks.
The period of time that may elapse after a risk has occurred before its impact is discovered.
The period of time before the risk might have an impact on one or more project objectives.

text: You are a project manager for a project which is facing the following risks: 20% chance a supplier will not deliver the needed spare parts on time, creating an additional cost of $30,000; 10% chance product may need rework adding a cost of $12,000; 25% chance the project will finish earlier than planned, so saving lease cost of $8,000. What is the expected monetary value of these risks?
explanation: EMV = 0.2*30,000+0.1*12,000-0.25*8,000 Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 435 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 176*

text: During planning a construction project, you asked project team members to pay attention to secondary risks. A new team member who has never worked on project before asked you what is meant by secondary risks, you answered him that secondary risks are:
explanation: The secondary risks are risks that arise as a direct result of implementing a risk response. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 439 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 125

choices.text: Discovered during the Identify Risks process.
New risks created by the risk response strategies selected.
Risks that remain after the Plan Risk Responses process.
Lower priority or low impact risks not requiring mitigation efforts.

text: You are the project manager of the new electro-mechanical project for your company. You identified risks with project stakeholders and performed qualitative and quantitative risk analysis. You planned risk responses for all top risks. The sponsor asked you to document how and when risk audits will be performed in the project. Where should you document the risk audits policy?
explanation: The project manager is responsible for ensuring that risk audits are performed at an appropriate frequency, as defined in the project’s risk management plan. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 456

choices.text: In the Risk Management Plan
In the Risk Register
In the Risk Response Plan
In the Risk Report

text: Andrew is a project manager for a construction project. He is identifying risks for a new construction project with his team members and stakeholders. They discovered that the wall painting material they are using on the building cannot be used in rainy conditions. They will use these paints during the time when most of the rainfall happens in this part of the country. The project can’t be delayed after the rainy season and he needs to make sure the building is painted. He decides that his team will just have to allow enough time in the schedule for non-worked rain days. This is an example of which risk response strategy?
explanation: The team can’t do anything about the weather, so the project manager has accepted the fact that they could end up being delayed by it. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 443 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 123

choices.text: Mitigate
Escalate
Accept
Transfer

text: Which of the following statements best describes risk audits?
explanation: In risk audits an external auditor reviews risk response strategies to ensure that risk management process are taken seriously and are used to collect lessons learned for future projects. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 456

choices.text: The project manager reviews each risk on the risk register with the team.

text: Sandra is a project manager for a software project. During project executing a problem has occurred. The problem was not discussed at all during project planning and it was not added to the risk register. The problem will cause one week delay to the project schedule. explanation: Management reserves are a specified amount of the project duration withheld for management control purposes and are reserved for unforeseen work that is within scope of the project. choices.text: Accept the risk and accept the delay because you can not create a response after the problem has occurred.

Ask for support from your management.

text: Sergio is the project manager for an IT project. He receives a phone call from Harold, a risk owner, who informed him that an identified threat has occurred. Harold implemented the contingency plan but it was inadequate. Which of the following is the best response for Sergio?

Perform Quantitative Risk Analysis

Acceptance

text: Jim is managing a large industrial project. His project is halfway done, when he held a meeting with the project team and other stakeholders to identify new risks and reevaluate the current risks. This practice is known as:
explanation: Risk review is a meeting to analyze the status of existing risks and identify new risks. This includes determining if the risk is still active and if there have been changes to the risk attributes (such as probability, impact, urgency, etc.). Risk identification

text: You are managing a software project in an agile development environment. After the first round of risk identification, a team member who has never worked in agile environment asks you when the qualitative risk analysis is performed. What would be your answer?

choices.text: During project planning.

After the first round of risk identification.

text: Linda is a project manager for a large tele-communication project. She is planning for risk management with her team. She holds a brainstorming session to discover and evaluate potential project risks. Which of the following methods can they use in prioritizing these risks?

choices.text: Tornado Diagram

text: An advantage and a disadvantage of using checklists in risk identification:

choices.text: Simple to use and can't be used alone.
Easy to calculate probability and impact and quiet people may not contribute.

choices.text: Risk Register
The watchlist
Risk Management Plan
Risk Report

text: If a risk event has a 80% chance of occurring, and the consequences will be a $100,000 loss, what does $80,000 represent?
explanation: Expected monetary value is calculated by multiplying the probability and impact of a risk event. EMV = P * I = 100000 * 0.8 = 80000 Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 435 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 176

Contingency budget
Risk value
Expected monetary value

text: Adam is a project manager for an electronic board design project. The project has a 50% chance of making cost saving for the company $215,000 over the next year. It has a 30% chance of costing the company $120,000. What's the project’s expected monetary value?
explanation: $215,000 x 0.5 = $ 107,500 savings, and $120,000 x 0.30 = - $36,000 expenses. Add them together and you get $71,500 Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 435 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 176

text: Which of the following statements best describes when risk identification is performed during the project?
explanation: Risk identification process is performed throughout the project. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 409 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 122

choices.text: During project planning and project monitoring and controlling.
Whenever there is a change to the project.
During project planning.
Throughout the project.

text: During the Plan Risk Responses process, the project team is analyzing ways to deal with a top risk. A team member suggests to assign the activity to a more experienced team members. Another one suggests to do the risky activities at the beginning of the project or to ignore the risk. The project manager suggests to insure against the risky activity. A functional manager suggests to wait to see if the risk happens. Which of the following is a risk response strategy that the team has forgotten to do?
explanation: Risk avoidance is the only strategy which is not mentioned here. Removing the activity which causes the risk is risk avoidance. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 443 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 123

choices.text: Remove the activity which causes the risk from the project.
Provide more training to team members.
Outsource the activity.
Decrease probability or impact of the risk.

text: You are a project manager of a software project when a previously unidentified risk is discovered. Your project is near completion and this risk may delay project completion date. What should you do next?
explanation: The risk here has been discovered, but hasn't occurred yet. So the best choice is to identify the risk and its impacts and add the risk to the risk register. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 411

choices.text: Assign a risk response owner to the discovered risk.
Reevaluate the Identify Risks process.
Create a workaround.
Qualify the risk.

text: You are managing a large IT project. Midway through the project, you learn that new equipment is needed to support project delivery. The procurement specialist has informed you that there will be a delay in the delivery of the needed equipment due to custom clearance and shipping lead time which will negatively impact your project timeline. What should you do next?
explanation: First things first. There is a delay risk which will have a negative impact on the project. So, a risk should be identified and added to the risk register and inform stakeholders about the probable delay. . Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 411 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 122

choices.text: Communicate this risk to the project stakeholders and add an entry in the risk register.
Search for local suppliers to provide the needed equipment.
Escalate to senior management and ask for support.
Raise a change request to extend the project timeline.

text: You are a project manager for electronic boards manufacturing project. Your team has identified a risk with some of the electronic components you are using on your project. Some of these electronic components may be defected, based on past projects, you've figured out that there's a high probability that about 18% of the electronic components may be faulty. You decide to buy an extra 20% of the electronic components so that you will be prepared for those defects and your project won't be delayed. Which response strategy are you using?
explanation: By purchasing extra components, you mitigate the risk. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 443 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 123

choices.text: Avoid
Accept
Mitigate

text: What is the purpose of a risk workshop?
explanation: To undertake risk identification, the project team may conduct a specialized meeting (often called a risk workshop). Most risk workshops include some form of brainstorming, but other risk identification techniques may be included. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 416

choices.text: The project team may conduct risk workshops for reassessment of current risks, the closing of risks that are outdated.

The project team may conduct risk workshops for risk identification.

text: Midway through the project, three team members have resigned from the organization. This may delay the activities assigned to them. This risk was already addressed during project planning. No action has been taken after their resignation. What should the project manager do?
explanation: The project manager should review the risk register as the risk was already addressed, so there should be a risk response. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 417 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 185

choices.text: Schedule a meeting with the project team to plan for risk response.
Visit the risk register.
Contact the HR department and ask for support.

text: You are managing a product design project. You are identifying risks with your team. You identified a risk that a supplier may not deliver material on time. choices.text: Secondary risks
Residual risks

choices.text: In the positive risk register
In the risk register
In the watchlist

choices.text: Watchlist and Risk Breakdown Structure

Risk Response Plan and Risk Report

text: To determine how accurate and well understood the risk information on the project is, it must be analyzed. And also you need to determine whether more research is needed before a qualitative assessment can be done. It is most important to complete which of the following?
explanation: Risk data quality assessment evaluates the degree to which the data about individual project risks is accurate and reliable as a basis for qualitative risk analysis. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 423

choices.text: Decision tree analysis
Sensitivity analysis
Monte Carlo analysis

explanation: A risk owner, who will be responsible for planning an appropriate risk response and for reporting progress on managing the risk, will be allocated to each individual project risk as part of the Perform Qualitative Risk Analysis process. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 426

choices.text: Identify Risks
Plan Risk Responses
Perform Qualitative Risk Analysis
Perform Quantitative Risk Analysis

text: A risk with high detectability means that:

choices.text: Risk urgency can be detected easily.
Risk manageability can be detected easily.

choices.text: Identify Risks
Plan Quality Management
Manage Quality

text: Midway through a sprint, a functional manager has withdrawn a developer form the agile team to complete some previously uncompleted tasks from another project. So, the team will not be able to meet their sprint goal. What should have been done to avoid this issue?

Mitigation
Avoidance

explanation: Avoidance means removing the risk by removing the cause, and here you removed the supplier who causes the risk. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 443 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 123.

choices.text: Transference
Mitigation
Avoidance
Acceptance

text: Midway through the project, the project manager discovers that he has missed some risks during project planning. The project is now being executed, and the project management plan has been approved. Which of the following actions should the project manager do regarding the new risks?

PMBOK 6th edition, Page 215 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 59.

choices.text: Re-evaluate the risk identification process.

choices.text: Risks
Threats
Risk categories
Opportunities

text: Julian is managing a construction project. He has determined that an activity is too risky to be completed internally. So, he hires a contractor to complete the activity. explanation: Secondary risks are risks that arise as a direct result of implementing a risk response. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 439 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 125.

choices.text: Residual risk
Secondary risk
Transference

explanation: As new risks are identified, they should be assessed, and risk responses should be planned. If they need extra budget or time to address them, they should be requested through integrated change control. Risk identification is an ongoing process. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 215 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 59.

choices.text: Re-evaluate the risk identification process.
The new risks might happen or not; identify them and don't request additional budget or time until they actually occur.

text: You are a project manager for a construction project when you discover that the local city council is about to install sewage systems. text: Richard is managing an online shopping website development project. He and the project team have finished the website design and got it approved from the customer and the project board. text: A risk has remained even after you implement all of your risk response strategies. What kind of risk is this and what should you do about it?

text: You work as a project manager for a risky construction project. You and your team have identified risks, then performed the qualitative and quantitative risk analysis with the help of experts. text: What is the difference between risk audit and risk reviews?
explanation: Risk audits are a type of audit that may be used to consider the effectiveness of the risk management process. The project manager is responsible for ensuring that risk audits are performed at an appropriate frequency, as defined in the project’s risk management plan. Risk reviews are scheduled regularly and should examine and document the effectiveness of risk responses in dealing with overall project risk and with identified individual project risks. Risk reviews may also result in identification of new individual project risks, reassessment of current risks and the closing of risks that are outdated. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 456 and 457

choices.text: They are the same.

Risk audits are used to consider the effectiveness of the risk management process, while risk reviews should examine and document the effectiveness of risk responses in dealing with overall project risk and with identified individual project risks.

Risk audits result in identification of new individual project risks, reassessment of current risks, and the closing of risks that are outdated, while risk reviews are used to consider the effectiveness of the risk management process.

The risk manager is responsible for ensuring that risk audits are performed at an appropriate frequency, as defined in the project’s risk management plan. While, the project manager is responsible for conducting risk reviews meetings.

text: Which of the following risk response strategies indicate that the project management plan will not be changed?
