However product reviews occur more frequently as it is done for each iteration in the project. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 163 and Agile Practice Guide, Page 55

choices.text: Validate Scope
Control Quality
Close Project or Phase
No, it is not similar to any traditional process.

text: During a sprint retrospective, the project team discuss the issues they faced during the sprint. One of these issues is that the team has committed to complete 50 story points, however they completed only 30 story points. What might be the most likely root cause of this issue?
explanation: As the team has committed to complete a certain number of story points in a sprint, so the team members know their capacity and capabilities. So, there should not be any need for additional resources. Agile teams normally estimate their tasks in real time, so meetings should not have an effect on their estimates. The best answer is that the team might have underestimated their work. It was more complex than what they estimated, that is why it was not completed during the sprint. Domain = Process. Agile Practice Guide, Page 55

choices.text: The complexity of the work was underestimated.
There were many meetings and interruptions during the sprint.
More resources were needed to complete the committed work.
Some team members were assigned later after the sprint has started.

text: The hardware design phase has reached its end. This phase is a part of a three-phase sequential project. All of the following actions should be performed before announcing that the design phase has been formally closed except:
explanation: Making sure that resources are available for the next phase is a part of the next phase work not the current phase. All other choices must be done before formally closing the phase. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 123 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 47

choices.text: Making sure that project knowledge has been shared and transferred for using in future projects.
Measuring project success or failure according to the success criteria.
Making sure that resources are available for the next phase.
Finalizing all open claims with the contracted sellers in this phase.

text: Which of the following events is most related to agile principle "At regular intervals, the team reflects on how to become more effective, then tunes and adjusts its behavior accordingly"?
explanation: Agile methods employ “retrospectives” which are frequent lookbacks to reflect on how things are working on the project and identify opportunities for improvements. These retrospectives are typically done at the end of each iteration, ensuring that the team has regular opportunities to review their process. Domain = Process. Agile Practice Guide Page 8 and 50

choices.text: Retrospective
Sprint review
Sprint planning meeting
Backlog refinement

text: One of the important activities to be done in project closing is archiving project documents. Why should the project documents be archived?
explanation: The main goal of archiving project documents is to be used in future similar projects. Domain = Process. PMBOK 7th edition, Page 149 and PMBOK 7th edition, Page 47

choices.text: To obtain the final acceptance from the customer.
To be used in future similar projects by the organization.
To update the organizational process assets.
To deliver to project sponsor.

text: All of a sudden, the inflation rate in the country where the project is performed went very high within few days. So the sponsor decided to terminate the ongoing project in this country. What should the project manager do first?
explanation: For terminated or completed projects, project closure procedures must be followed. Project closure procedures include more than releasing resources and reallocating facilities.

choices.text: Release resources, reallocate project facilities and return back to his organization.
Meet with the sponsor and try to convince him to find ways to complete the project.
Try to deal with a different currency than the currency of the country where you implement the project to mitigate the risk.
Follow the project closure procedures.

text: George is managing a three-phase sequential project to clean up a hazardous waste site. The three phases are facility decommissioning, waste removal, and landscaping. The transition from waste removal to landscaping is typically marked by:
explanation: A phase gate or kill point is held at the end of a phase. The project’s performance and progress are compared to project and business documents. Domain = Process. PMBOK 6th edition, Page 21

choices.text: Kill Point
Constraint
Decision tree
Transition phase

text: A project team received training on the technology involved with a project deliverable. In nine months of working on the project, several team members have been replaced. Productivity has slowed because new team members are not familiar with the technology and the project schedule is at risk of delay. What should the project manager do?
explanation:
this option is the fastest and most efficient to get through the problem without delays or increased costs. Utilizing the expertise of existing members to enhance cohesion within the team and save time and resources is better than starting a long formal training or bringing in new members.

Other options are ineffective as a first step: Negotiating with the project sponsor to increase the budget is a late and costly option. Issuing a change request to recruit new members is impractical because it causes additional delays and affects team cohesion. Facilitating a workshop with a subject matter expert is a good idea but it's expensive and time-consuming, so it's not the best option at first.

choices.text: Meet with the entire team and ask existing members to train the new team members.
Negotiate an increase in budget with the project sponsor for additional training for the new team members.
Issue a change request for new team members already trained in the relevant technology.
Facilitate a workshop with a subject matter expert to familiarize team members with the technology.

text: The day before construction is scheduled to begin, the project manager learns that the structure blueprint was not accepted by the customer. What should the project manager do first to ensure that the project timeline is met?
explanation:
This step directly addresses the problem and helps to reach an agreement or urgent correction before it affects the start of construction work. Since the schedule is threatened, the immediate solution is to communicate directly with the customer to determine exactly what is required and avoid delays.

Wrong options explained:
- Start building by appointment while reviewing the plan with the customer at the same time: This is an irresponsible and dangerous option because starting work without formal approval may result in rework and additional costs.
- Discuss the process of accepting output components with the customer:  This is a very general option and does not address the current immediate problem.
- Review the stakeholder engagement plan and expectations: While important in the long run, it is not the appropriate action as a first step in a crisis situation that requires immediate intervention with the customer.

choices.text: Meet with the customer as soon as possible to discuss changes to the blueprint.
Begin construction as scheduled while simultaneously reviewing the blueprint with the customer.
Discuss the process of deliverable component acceptance with the customer.
Review the stakeholder engagement plan and stakeholder expectations.

text: A project manager learns that the project team will miss a milestone because team member A has not completed the task requirements needed by team member B. When meeting with team member A, what should the project manager do?
explanation:
This step represents a supportive and analytical leadership style, where the project manager investigates the root causes of non-achievement and provides the necessary support, whether it is training or removing obstacles.

Wrong choices explained:
- A: Not responsible, transferring responsibility without addressing the cause is not an effective solution.
- C: A quick but superficial solution, which does not address the problem at its root.
- D: To avoid the problem, the member must be helped, not eliminated or replaced.

choices.text: Direct team member A to turn over the responsibilities for completing the task requirements to team member B.
Identify any obstacles to meeting the task requirements and determine if team member A needs help completing them.
Ask team member A to work directly with team member B to complete the requirements in order to meet the milestone.
Ask team member A to recommend a replacement who can complete the task requirements.

text: A technology project has members of a project team from multiple countries. The stakeholders have stated that this arrangement will keep the project within budget. However, the project manager believes that the stakeholders have not accounted for issues that might arise that could affect the success of the project.nnWhat should the project manager do to record this concern?
explanation:
What the project manager mentioned is the possibility of a future problem such as timing or communication issues, and these fall under risk management because they have not yet occurred.

Wrong choices explained:
- B: Modifying the stakeholder interaction plan is not appropriate because the concern here is about potential risks and not about stakeholder interaction.
- A: Recording the information in the issue log is not appropriate because the problem has not yet occurred, it is only a possibility.
- D: Updating the resource management plan does not address the concern about potential risks indicated by the project manager.

choices.text: Document the risks in the risk register.
Revise the stakeholder engagement plan.
Capture the information in the issues log.
Update the resource management plan.

text: Two stakeholders inform the project manager that the status of a critical project phase was not communicated to them. Although the project phase is in these stakeholders' area of interest, the stakeholders have only recently been identified. What should the project manager do first?
explanation:
The reason is that new stakeholders have recently been identified, and it is important to identify their interests and level of influence and ensure that they are formally included in the communication plan. Updating the stakeholder register allows their expectations to be managed and ensures their inclusion in upcoming communications.

Explanation  of the wrong choices:
- Review the communication management plan: An important step but it comes after knowing who the new stakeholders are and updating the record.
- Identify new ways to send project status reports: A subsequent action after updating the stakeholder record.
- Schedule a project status meeting and invite new stakeholders:  useful but not the first step before updating and evaluating stakeholders' roster.

choices.text: Review the communications management plan.
Perform a stakeholder analysis and update the stakeholder register.
Identify new ways to send project status reports to all stakeholders.
Schedule a status meeting and invite the two new stakeholders.

text: A project in the execution phase is on track and within budget. A key stakeholder requests a change in communication frequency. They want to discontinue receiving weekly status reports and instead be notified only if an issue arises that requires their attention.nnWhat should the project manager do?
explanation:
The communications management plan defines how to communicate with stakeholders, frequency of reports, type of information, and how it is communicated. When there is a formal request from a key stakeholder to change the frequency of communication, this plan should be updated to ensure that their expectations are met and communication is effective.

Wrong choices:
- Review the stakeholder engagement plan to determine the extent of that party's involvement: An important step but not the first action after the change request, because the stakeholder engagement plan focuses on the level of stakeholder participation and not the specific method of communication.
- Ask other stakeholders if they also want to reduce the number of notifications: It can lead to delays and confusion, as each stakeholder has their own preferences and must be respected individually.
- Meeting with the stakeholder to discuss the amount and type of information to communicate: While the discussion is useful, the first practical step is to formally modify the communications plan as requested.

Modifying the communication plan ensures that the change is documented, which facilitates follow-up and reduces confusion. The change must be implemented quickly to avoid sending non-information Desirable affect stakeholder satisfaction. Effective communication with stakeholders contributes to the success and satisfaction of the project.

choices.text: Review the stakeholder engagement plan to ascertain the stakeholder's involvement.
Ask the other stakeholders if they would also like less frequent notifications.
Revise the communications management plan to reflect the stakeholder's request.
Meet with the stakeholder to discuss the amount and type of information that should be communicated.

text: A project manager is leading a project with an aggressive timeline that requires fast time to market because a competitor is working on a similar product. The project team cannot meet the go live date, and there are no other internal resources that can assist with the project.nnHow should the project manager mitigate this risk?
explanation:
When internal resources are insufficient or unavailable, outsourcing is an effective strategy to reduce the risk of delays and ensure deadlines are met. This allows additional expertise to be provided or increased production capacity without the need for permanent hiring or team restructuring.

Errors in other options:
- Require the team to remove obstacles that prevent them from meeting the operational date:  While removing obstacles is important, the problem here is a lack of resources, and this option does not address the root cause.
- Ask the project sponsor to set a new run date based on available resources: Changing the date should be a last option after trying to mitigate the risk, not the first step.
- Ask the team to focus only on the basic features and stick to the run date:  Reducing the scope of work (minimization) may be a valid strategy but it is not mentioned here as an option, and without additional resources, it may not be enough to meet the appointment.

In short, outsourcing is the most appropriate solution to mitigate the risk of delays in this context.

choices.text: Look for external resources who can assist in meeting the required go live date.
Ask the team to remove the obstacles preventing them from meeting the go live date.
Ask the project sponsor to set a new go live date based on available resources.
Ask the team to focus only on the critical features and meet the go live date.

text: A project manager is formally closing a project that has been completed. Why should the project manager document final project activities?
explanation:
This helps organizations improve future operations by leveraging the experience gained, and is an important part of knowledge management. In addition, this ensures that important documents that may be used in future projects or performance review are preserved.

Wrong choices:
- Recording client case studies and references: This is not the primary function of documenting final activities.
- Recording final project performance indicators and quality analysis: While this information is important, it is part of the technical reports and not the primary reason for documenting the final activities.
- Allow the customer to submit invoices and receive the final payment receipt: these are financial procedures and are not part of documenting the final activities of the project.

choices.text: To record case studies and customer references
To log final project performance metrics and quality analysis
To provide lessons learned and archive historical information
To allow the customer to submit invoices and get a receipt of final payment

text: Two key stakeholders, who are also members of the change control board (CCB), complain they were not aware of an extension to the project schedule. The project manager knows that the extension was necessary to add value to the project.nnWhat should the project manager have done to avoid this issue?
explanation:
In managing change within projects, especially when it comes to changes that affect the schedule, communication with key stakeholders is absolutely essential. These stakeholders are also members of the Change Control Board (CCB), which means they should be aware of all the steps that affect the project.

The main error in the case is not consulting them before submitting a formal change request. This may cause frustration for them and lead to problems with communication and trust.

- Why is consultation important?
Consultationensures that stakeholders understand and agree to the reasons for the change before completing the process. This enhances transparency and helps reduce future objections or issues.

- Why are other options wrong?
- Submitting a change request without consultation: leads to a lack of transparency and angers stakeholders.
- Conducting a what-if analysis: This is a good technical step but not the right start in communicating with stakeholders.
- Asking the project sponsor about a time margin: It is not directly related to informing stakeholders.

choices.text: Submitted a change request to the entire CCB without discussing it first with the stakeholders.
Run a what-if analysis to determine the impact of the change.
Asked the project sponsor if there was any float in the project schedule.
Consulted the stakeholders before following the established change process.

text: In an iteration review, the definition of done (DoD) was not met.nnWhat is an appropriate way for the project manager to proceed?
explanation:
When  the definition of Done (DoD) is not met, it means that the output or features did not meet the specific requirements that make the work complete. The correct course of action is to identify the root cause of this problem with the team during the Retrospective meeting, and then propose a plan to address the deficiencies to ensure continuous improvement.

- Why the right choice?
This approach is analytical and collaborative, encouraging the team to identify problems and work to improve performance and quality.

- Why are other options wrong?
- Request for Charter Update and Reappointment of Authorities: A formal and heavy procedure that does not address the immediate issue.
- Request to develop new features: May result in adding unwanted work without understanding the underlying cause.
- Submit a change request with additional budget: Financial changes should not be requested without radically identifying and resolving the problem first.

choices.text: Ask the project sponsor to update the project charter and reassign the authorities and responsibilities.
Request that the project team develop new features to replace the features that were rejected.
Determine the root cause with the team in the retrospective meeting and suggest plan to address the deficiencies.
Send a new change request to the change control board (CCB) for approval, adding budget to the baseline.

text: A sponsor proposes a project scope change that is popular with the project team and key stakeholders. What should the project manager do?
explanation:
The project manager must follow the formal change management process to ensure that the amendment is properly documented, reviewed, and approved before it is implemented.

-The change management process maintains control over the scope of the project and prevents random changes that may affect the schedule or budget.

- Why are other options wrong?
- Inform stakeholders: Just reporting is insufficient without following the formal process.
- Project requirements update: occurs only after formal approval.
- Modification of the structure of the workload: After approval and formal updating of the scope.

choices.text: Follow the change management process.
Notify stakeholders of the change.
Update the project requirements.
Modify the work breakdown structure (WBS).

text: An external provider is late with the delivery of a finished item. As a measure of goodwill, and to maintain the project's schedule, the provider offers to bear the cost of renting a temporary system.nnSince no schedule slippage will occur, what should the project manager do next?
explanation:
Although the proposed solution does not affect the schedule, it represents a change in costs, resources or procedures, so an integrated change control process must be applied.

-Any change (even if it seems to have no impact on the output) must go through this process to ensure that it is documented, reviewed, and the necessary approvals obtained.

- Why are the other options wrong?
- Resource insertion in WBS:  Inserted only after the change is approved.
- No action: Conflicts with systematic change policies.
- Project documents updated: only after formal approval of the change.

choices.text: Account for this additional resource in the work breakdown structure (WBS).
Take no further actions because there is no schedule slippage.
Conduct the Perform Integrated Change Control process.
Update the project documents.

text: A new project manager resumes a project in its execution phase. During a project status meeting, a team member reports an issue shared by a stakeholder.nnWhat should the new project manager do first?
explanation:
When a new project manager takes over and a reported issue arises, the first systematic step is to refer to the Issue Log  to confirm whether the issue is already documented, understand its context and act on the information provided.

- Returning to the problem log provides the basis for making decisions based on accurate and historical data.

- Why are other options wrong?
- Address the issue immediately: It may lead to ill-considered decisions without sufficient understanding.
- Stakeholder Plan Review: Not directly related to the current issue.
- Update the risk plan: The current problem is not a potential risk but an existing event.

choices.text: Review the issue log.
Immediately address the issue.
Review the stakeholder engagement plan.
Update the risk management plan.

text: A vendor submits a high-level project schedule for a three-year project, including a detailed design-phase schedule. What does this describe?
explanation:
This example reflects rolling wave planning, a gradual technique in which nearby activities are planned in great detail, while distant activities are generally planned. Details are gradually updated as the project progresses.

- Because the vendor provided a detailed schedule for an existing stage (design) only, while keeping the rest of the project high-level, this is the essence of progressive planning.

- Why are other options wrong?
Decomposition  : Refers to the division of the scope of work and not to staged scheduling.
Expert  judgment:  A technique used to make decisions based on experience, not a time-planning method.
  Templates: Tools that help in documentation or planning, but are not a method of dividing the schedule.

choices.text: Rolling wave planning
Decomposition
Expert judgment
Templates

text: To handle a change in requirements, a project team needs to be motivated and flexible to reprioritize tasks. What leadership style would help the team to perform well in changing and uncertain conditions?
explanation:
Collaborative Leadership is best suited in changing and uncertain environments. It focuses on empowering the team, encouraging innovation, and facilitating interaction among members to achieve common goals.

- Because a collaborative approach fosters motivation and continuous learning, and gives the team space to reprioritize and adapt to changes.

- Why are other options wrong?
• The directive approach focuses on controlling and commanding, and is less effective in environments that need flexibility.
• Documentation does not directly address the change in requirements.
• Adapting the vision is strategic, but agile leadership is more effective in managing the team during day-to-day changes.

choices.text: A collaborative approach will boost motivation, learning, growth, and innovation around a project vision.
A directive approach will boost team confidence by ensuring that team members only work on the tasks suited to their qualifications.
A collaborative approach will ensure that project procedures are well-documented and complete enough to cover all situations.
A directive approach will prepare the team for frequent changes by adapting the project vision to new directions.

text: After success in a particulary challenging project phase, a project manager reassigned a high-performing team member to a more strategic task.  This is an example of what?
explanation:
This example shows the use of  the recognition method, which is an important element in team management and performance motivation. When a project manager notices outstanding performance, rewarding this effort by assigning the person to more important tasks is a form of appreciation and motivation.

- Because reassigning a team member to a more strategic task is a kind of moral reward that recognizes their effort and superiority.

- Why are other options wrong?
• Risk acceptance: unrelated to assignment or performance.
• Mentorship: involves providing guidance and advice, not a new assignment.
• Change in scope: related to the scope of work in the project, not to human resources.

choices.text: Recognition
Risk acceptance
Mentorship
Scope change

text: A project manager is managing a project where requirements are fixed and the workflow is planned for the full development lifecycle. Additionally, the customer involvement is at specific milestones and testing happens post-build.nnWhich methodology should a project manager use for this project?
explanation:
Predictive methodology is used when the requirements are clear and fixed from the beginning, and the project is implemented in a linear sequence (e.g., planning, designing, building, and testing). This model is often known as 'Waterfall'.

-Because the project is based on fixed requirements, customer interaction is limited, and tests are carried out after the construction phase, all of this reflects the characteristics of the predictive methodology.

- Why are other options wrong?
•  Agile: Requires constant interaction with the customer, successive iterations, and adaptation to change.
•  Hybrid methodology: Combines agile and predictive, but the question clearly indicates the application of a linear sequence without elements of agile method.
•  Continuous Improvement: It is a concept of continuous process improvement, not a project management methodology.

choices.text: Agile
Hybrid
Predictive
Continuous Improvement

text: The project manager has identified all internal and external stakeholders in a project. The project manager now has to determine the best stakeholder engagement approach.nnWhat should the project manager do first?
explanation:
Stakeholder analysis is the essential step to understanding who the stakeholders are, what their interests are, and their level of impact on the project. This analysis helps identify appropriate strategies to interact with them effectively to ensure their support for the project.

The Create SWOT analysis option is not directly related to stakeholder management, but is used to analyze the strengths, weaknesses, opportunities, and threats of the project.

Option Develop a multi-criteria decision-making analysis that is used to make complex decisions rather than to determine how to interact with stakeholders.

The Fishbone Diagram design option is used to analyze the causes of problems and not to identify stakeholder strategies.

choices.text: Conduct a stakeholder analysis.
Create a SWOT analysis.
Develop a multicriteria decision analysis.
Design a fishbone diagram.

text: A project manager recently joined an organization that is implementing a portfolio of strategic initiatives aimed at enhancing profitability. The project manager reviews a past project's business case with the project sponsor to ensure that the project was aligned with the organization's goals and to learn from its successes and failures.nnWhich of the following project outcomes would be considered most successful in the context of this organization's strategic initiatives?
explanation:
This option reflects the achievement of the three main objectives: time, cost, and value added (increased sales), which indicates real strategic success.

The project was executed on a 25% lower budget, but took 20% longer shows a delay in time despite cost savings, which can negatively affect profitability.

The project was implemented within budget, and approved for closure by the PMO does not show a clear added value for the organization.

Option The project was delivered early, entered the market ahead of competitors, and exceeding the budget by 10% indicates cost overrun, which can affect profitability.

choices.text: The project was delivered under budget by 25%, and the overall duration was 20% longer than initially scheduled.
The project was delivered on budget, and the project management office (PMO) approved the project closure.
The project was delivered early, entered the market before the competition, and exceeded the budget by 10%.
The project was delivered on schedule, within budget, and yielded a 5% increase in projected product sales.

text: During project execution, the project manager realizes that a team member is not completing tasks in accordance with the project management plan. What is the first action the project manager should take?
explanation:
This procedure helps the project manager understand the obstacles or problems that the member faces, whether personal, technical, or environmental, enabling him to provide appropriate support to solve the problem and improve performance.

Wrong choices:
- Building a matrix team to review relationships in all project teams: An indirect procedure that does not address the current issue.
- Ask all team members to focus more on the project:  A generic, unspecified request that does not address the true cause of poor performance.
- Reassigning uncompleted tasks to another team member: May exacerbate the problem without understanding the root cause of poor performance.

choices.text: Build a matrix team to review the relationships on all project teams.
Ask all the team members to focus more on the project.
Reassign the uncompleted tasks to another team member.
Engage the team member to determine the reasons for poor performance.

text: A supplier of a critical component for a construction project notifies the project manager that the component will be significantly late. Because this risk had been identified during project planning, the cost baseline contains an adequate contingency reserve.nnWhat should the project manager do next?
explanation:
This delay was previously identified as a risk during the planning phase, and the contingency reserve is dedicated to addressing these risks to avoid budget overruns.
- Using the alternative resource within the reserve value allows the delay to be addressed without the need to request a formal change or cost increase.
- This procedure helps maintain the project schedule and minimize the negative impact.

Errors in other options:
- A component request from another vendor with a change request to the Change Control Board (CCB) is currently unnecessary because the reserve is in place to address this.
- The review of the risk response plan, the statement of work, and the penalty clause is important but must be done after practical action has been taken.
- Updating the schedule and repository of lessons learned is a next step and is not a priority at this moment.

choices.text: Identify a supplier that can provide the component within the amount of the reserve.
Order the component from another supplier and submit a change request to the change control board (CCB).
Review the risk response plan and the statement of work for the next steps and a penalty clause for late delivery.
Update the project schedule and the lessons learned repository.

text: A project is in the execution phase, and product testing is almost complete. A team member proposes that the testing can be fast-tracked by removing some of the tests. The team member believes this will help to finish the job earlier and give the project more float.nnWhat should the project manager do?
explanation:
Removing some tests can lead to quality risks, and the release of an incomplete or defective product, which may cost the project more time and resources in the long run.
- The extra time (float) in the table does not necessarily mean that the quality of the work must be sacrificed.
-  The project manager is responsible for ensuring product quality and adhering to the specified test standards.
- The proposal can be discussed or a study requested from the Quality Manager, but the initial rejection is the correct measure to maintain the quality of the project.

Other options:
- Requesting more information or discussing the proposal may be useful, but the first step should protect the quality of the project.
- Asking the quality manager to study the proposal can be later if there are compelling reasons, but it is not the first step.

choices.text: Request more information from the team member.
Reject the team member's proposal.
Discuss this proposal with the project team.
Ask the quality manager to consider the proposal.

text: Which of the following represents levels of risk attitude?
explanation:
Risk tolerance expresses how individuals or organizations deal with potential risks.
- Risk avoidance means refusal to take risks and unwillingness to take risks.
- Risk neutral means no inclination either to accept or avoid risk.
- Risk tolerant means accepting risks while minimizing them to an acceptable extent.
- Risk-seeking means seeking risk for greater gains or opportunities.

Errors in other options:
- Conservative, moderate, liberal are levels of general attitudes in other areas but are not common descriptions of risk situations.
- Reduce risk, avoid, transfer, and accept risk are risk management strategies, not psychological attitudes or risk attitudes.
- High, medium, low Describe risk risk levels rather than attitudes toward risk.
- Positive, negative, indifferent describe general trends but are not accurate classifications of risk situations.

choices.text: Conservative, moderate, and liberal
Risk-averse, risk-neutral, risk-tolerant, risk-seeking
Risk-mitigating, risk-avoiding, risk-transferring, risk-accepting
High, medium, and low
Positive, negative, and indifferent

text: A project manager completed plans for a project and submitted all documents for approval but did not allocate time for delays in obtaining approvals. In addition to selecting a risk owner to address this potential risk, what should the project manager have done?
explanation:
Allocating time for potential approval delays is part of robust risk management.
- Appointing a risk owner is a step forward, but it must be complemented by detailed plans to act on the risk if it occurs.
- Having a primary (Plan A) and contingency (Plan B) ensures continuity if the risk materializes.

Why the other options are incorrect:
- Escalation without a defined response plan may not be timely or effective.
- Reducing work estimates without adjusting scope, resources, or timeline is unrealistic and could cause project failure.
- Real options analysis is a useful tool, but it must follow the establishment of concrete mitigation strategies.

choices.text: Asked the risk owner to escalate with approvers so that approvals are obtained as soon as possible.
Adjusted the project plans by lowering work completion estimates so that the work can be completed on time despite the delay.
Developed specific actions to implement the agreed-upon risk response strategy, including primary and backup strategies.
Used a real options analysis to perform an economic analysis of alternative risk response strategies.

text: A project manager is conducting risk identification based on high-level scope and expert judgement.nnWhat information in the project charter could support risk identification?
explanation:
The project charter contains basic information that helps identify potential risks.
- Stakeholder interest helps the project manager understand who may be affected by or affected by the project, highlighting risks related to the expectations and impacts of these parties.
-  A summary of project roles and responsibilities provides information on the management structure but does not directly explain the risks.
- Detailed requirements and scope are usually in other documents and not in the project charter, and are important for project planning but less useful for identifying risks at the start-up stage.
Communication matrices manage communication channels but are not a direct source of risk identification.

Errors in other options:
- Every other option focuses on an important part of project management, but does not provide specific information to identify risks in the first phase.

choices.text: Summary of project roles and responsibilities
Detailed requirements and scope
Project communication matrices
Stakeholder interest

text: A project manager learned that the project deliverables will not meet the quality requirements unless a change is made to a component. After issuing a formal change request, the project manager emailed details of the change to all stakeholders. Most stakeholders received the information promptly and are fully aware of the change. However, the project manager finds out that some stakeholders did not receive the email or did not read it.nnWhat could the project manager have done to prevent this?
explanation:
The communication management plan specifies how, when, and by whom it receives information related to the project.
- Relying solely on e-mail may not be sufficient to ensure that the information is accessible to or aware of all stakeholders.
- Reviewing the plan allows the identification of alternative or additional communication channels to ensure that information is received effectively.
- Other options do not address the problem of communication directly or comprehensively.

Explain other options:
- Prepare a detailed report on work performance: useful but does not solve the problem of communication with stakeholders.
- Meeting with the project sponsor: may help, but not the first solution to ensure correct communication.
- Asking stakeholders about their knowledge of technology: Not related to the problem of communication about change.

choices.text: Reviewed the communications management plan.
Developed a detailed work performance report.
Met with the project sponsor to discuss communication.
Questioned the stakeholders about technological literacy.

text: A project sponsor is risk averse and is therefore concerned about negative impacts on the project. To help with this concern, the project team identifies four project risks and then evaluates both the probability of occurrence and the impact of the risk if it occurs. The team uses a 1-5 scale, 1 being the lowest and 5 being the highest.nnn n n Riskn Probabilityn Impactn n 3n 3n 5n 1n n 2n 2n 4n n dn 4n 4n nnnBased on the table, in what order should the project manager rank these risks (high to low) for risk management purposes?
explanation:
To prioritize risk management by risk, the risk level is calculated by multiplying the probability by impact for each risk:

- Risk A: 3 × 3 = 9
- Risk B: 5 × 1 = 5
- Risk C: 2 × 4 = 8
- Risk D: 4 × 4 = 16

Therefore, the risk should be ranked by value from high to low:
d (16), a (9), c (8), b (5).

 This arrangement helps the project manager to focus first on the risks with the highest impact and probability.
- Classifying risks in this way facilitates making decisions based on the priority of effective risk management.

Explanation of the wrong choices:
- Options that start with risk B prioritize low-impact risks, which is not suitable for effective risk management.
-  The risk ranking is based on the product of probability and impact and not on probability or impact only.

choices.text: B, A, D, C
B, C, A, D
D, A, C, B
C, D, A, B

text: A project manager has been made aware of a recent weather event that could potentially impact the project. Forecasters are unable to predict the path or strength of the event. Any delays would extend the project's finish date and cause cost overruns.n What should the project manager do first?
explanation:
The first correct step is to review the pre-existing risk log, as this event is likely to have been identified as a potential hazard and planned how to deal with or monitor it. Reviewing the risk log helps the project manager make informed decisions and assess the team's readiness for this event.

- Because the event is a potential hazard and not an existing issue, you should refer to the risk log for planned actions or update them.

- Why are other options wrong?
- Inform stakeholders and update budget: a next step after the risk assessment, not the first action.
- Take preventive action based on new information: Not possible without a thorough risk assessment and preparation.
- Record the event in the Issue log: The event has not yet become a problem, so it should not be recorded as a problem record.

choices.text: Notify the stakeholders and revise the budget.
Take preventive action based on new information.
Check the risk register for more risk information.
Record information about the event in the issue log.

text: A project manager learns that in-house resources are insufficient to produce a critical component of a deliverable. This poses a significant threat. The quality of the component is integral to the project, and the in-house resources cannot guarantee high-quality output. In response to this threat, the project manager decides to outsource the production of the component by contracting a third-party vendor.n Which threat response strategy did the project manager use?
explanation:
The strategy used here is mitigation, where the project manager decided to reduce the risk of not achieving the required quality by hiring an external supplier who can deliver higher quality. Mitigation means taking action to reduce the likelihood or impact of a risk.

-Becausethe manager did not accept the risk as it is, did not strengthen or escalate it, but took practical action to reduce the possibility of negative impact.

- Why are other options wrong?
- Acceptance: means taking the risk without taking action, which is not true here.
- Reinforcement: means increasing the chances of the risk occurring or impact, which is inappropriate.
- Escalation: It means transferring risk management to a higher destination, which is not what happened.

choices.text: Accept
Mitigate
Enhance
Escalate

text: A technology project for a multinational bank is in the testing stage. The project manager learns that a security breach has exposed the personal data of thousands of end users. The project sponsor suspends work while the cause is investigated. The threat of a security breach was identified during the risk management planning process, and the impact is significant.n What should the project manager do?
explanation:
When a major security breach classified as an issue occurs, the project manager should update the issue log to reflect this new event, and also review the risk response strategy in the risk log to see if the planned actions are effective or need to be modified.

- Because the security breach has become an actual problem and must be dealt with as such with the relevant documentation updated.

- Why are other options wrong?
- Refer to the stakeholder engagement plan: Not the first step to dealing with the security breach.
- Perform a decision tree analysis: It may be useful later but the first step is to update the records.
- Meeting with the project sponsor: A next step after documenting the issue and reviewing the strategy.

choices.text: Refer to the stakeholder engagement plan to determine the risk owner.
Perform a decision tree analysis to calculate the optimal path to resolution.
Meet with the project sponsor to negotiate a new requirements management plan.
Update the issue log and review the risk response strategy outlined in the risk register.

text: An electronic company plans to launch a new line of smart home devices. The devices will require a wide variety of skills to produce. However, the company's current production team does not have all of the necessary skills. What is the most comprehensive way for the project manager to identify and address the potential risks of delivering the new product?
explanation:
High-level risk assessment is a comprehensive technique that a project manager can use to identify all potential risks that a project may face, including a lack of skills in the team. This assessment can include technical, organizational, and HR-related risks and allow plans to address them comprehensively.

 Because it allows for a thorough understanding of potential risks rather than focusing on only a specific aspect.

- Why are other options wrong?
- Modifying the scope of the project: It may be a later solution but it does not help identify risks.
-  Quality control requirements review: focused on quality and does not cover all types of risks.
- Analysis of the production process of competitors: It may help improve processes but is not a direct method of identifying risks.

choices.text: Revise the project scope
Review quality control requirements
Assess high-level risks
Analyze the competitor's production process

text: A new  project manager is assigned to replace a project manager who has resigned. During the initial assessment of project documentation, the new project manager discovers that the risk register has not been updated for several weeks. The project manager's next step be to consult the risk management plan. Why?
explanation:
Referring to the risk management plan helps the new project manager understand the method the previous manager used to classify and prioritize risks. This is essential to understand current priorities and deal with risks in a systematic manner consistent with the project management style.

-Because the risk management plan contains risk assessment and ranking criteria, enabling the new manager to accurately understand the current risk management status.

- Why are other options wrong?
- Determine the number of times risks have appeared in the past: Not directly related to the risk management plan.
- Know how often the risk register is updated: only procedural information and does not help in the risk assessment.
- Determining the level of acceptable uncertainty: Part of the risk assessment but not the main reason for returning to the plan.

choices.text: To determine how often risks have emerged in the past.
To understand how the previous manager prioritized risks.
To learn how often the risk register must be updated.
To ascertain the level of uncertainty acceptable for the project

text: At the first team meeting, the project manager uses the risks noted in the project charter as a starting point for developing the risk register. After identifying the risks, what should the project team do next?
explanation:
After identifying the risks, the next step is to assess these risks by creating a probability and impact matrix. This matrix helps prioritize risks based on how likely they are to occur and their impact on the project, enabling the team to focus on the most important risks and plan for their response effectively.

-Because creating a probability and impact matrix is a standard method for assessing and prioritizing risks.

- Why are other options wrong?
- Management reserve calculation: is carried out after risk assessment and identification of response strategies.
- Development of emergency response strategies: comes after risk assessment and classification.
- Conduct of identification and classification activity: already done in the previous stage.

choices.text: Calculate the management reserve.
Develop contingent response strategies.
Populate a probability and impact matrix.
Perform identification and categorization activity.

text: A project manager is reviewing work performance data in preparation for the close project process. The data reveals that one of the deliverables was not accepted. The estimated work required to complete acceptance of the deliverable will delay the project completion date by two months.nnWhat should the project manager do next?
explanation:
When it is discovered that the project output is unacceptable and requires additional work that leads to a delay in the schedule, the project manager must issue a formal change request to modify the schedule. This procedure is done through the Change Control Board (CCB) to ensure that the change is reviewed and approved within the formal project management processes.

- Issuing a change request is the correct procedure to manage delays that affect the project baseline and require formal approval.

- Why are other options wrong?
- Allocation of contingency reserve: This is not done without formal review and schedule update.
- Schedule update and work performed: Not possible before the change is approved.
- Update the watch list in the risk log: This is a secondary step and does not address the actual delay.

choices.text: Allocate the contingency reserve to procure resources needed for completion.
Update the schedule and perform the work.
Issue a change request for review by the change control board (CCB).
Update the watch list in the risk register.

text: A major project deliverable is completed. What should the project manager and team do to confirm that specifications have been met?
explanation:
Upon completion of a key output, the project manager and team must perform quality control to ensure that the output meets the specifications and requirements specified in the project plan. Quality control involves checking products or outputs to verify their compliance with standards, and detecting and correcting defects before delivering the output.

-Because quality control ensures that the outputs conform to the required standards and specifications.

- Why are the other options wrong?
-  Process organizational asset validation: supporting documentation and does not reflect product verification.
- Quality audit reports: results reports, not actual verification activity.
- Scope verification: focuses on determining what to include, not checking the quality of outputs.

choices.text: Check the organizational process assets.
Validate the quality audit reports.
Verify the scope.
Perform quality control.

text: The client agreed to the standards that would be used to assess final deliverables prior to hand-off, but is now asking for improvements because the deliverables do not meet the standards. Which document should the project manager consult to resolve this issue?
explanation:
When the client requests improvements to the outputs due to their non-conformity with the agreed standards, the project manager should refer to the quality management plan. This plan contains the standards, processes, and methods for verifying the quality of the outputs that have been agreed upon with the customer.

-Because the quality management plan determines how to measure and evaluate the quality of outputs, which helps resolve disputes about the conformity of the product to standards.

- Why are other options wrong?
-  The scope management plan focuses on defining what will be delivered, but does not specify quality standards.
- Requirements documentation describes what the customer needs, but does not specify detailed evaluation criteria.
-  The project charter sets out objectives and authorities, but does not contain details of quality standards.

choices.text: Scope management plan
Quality management plan
Requirements documentation
Project charter

text: A project deliverable does not meet the functional requirements necessary to meet stakeholder needs. As a result, the customer refuses to accept the deliverable.nnHow would define the quality metrics have helped the project manager avoid this situation?
explanation:
Defining quality metrics means defining what characteristics the output must have and how to measure these characteristics to ensure that functional requirements are met. These metrics help to verify the quality of the output before presenting it to the customer and thus reduce the likelihood of rejection.

- Why the right choice?
Qualitymetrics clearly define product characteristics and explain methods of measuring them, allowing accurate quality control.

- Why are other options wrong?
- The test management plan focuses on job verification but does not cover the definition of comprehensive metrics.
-  The workflow structure (WBS) does not define quality standards but focuses on the division of work.
-  The requirements plan is not associated with procurement in cases of failure.

choices.text: The test management plan would have evaluated the deliverable according to quality metrics before final acceptance.
Quality metrics specified in the work breakdown structure (WBS) would have identified compliance specifications.
Quality metrics would have described the attributes of the deliverable and how to measure them.
Quality metrics in the requirements plan would have allowed for a new procurement process in case of component failure.

text: After sponsor approval of a project, the project manager invites the sponsor, selected team members, and other stakeholders to a meeting. The major purpose of the meeting is to define how formal acceptance of the completed project deliverables will be obtained.nnWhat document will be developed as the final output of this meeting?
explanation:
The goal of the meeting is to determine how to obtain formal acceptance of the output, and this requires updating or developing a domain management plan that explains how to document acceptance and how to deal with changes associated with the scope.

- Domain management plan defines the procedures and processes related to the formal identification and acceptance of the scope.

- Why are other options wrong?
- A change log is a record that tracks changes but is not a domain acceptance document.
-  A stakeholder registry focuses on stakeholder interaction and not domain acceptance.
- A requirements management plan focuses on documenting requirements but is not a domain acceptance document.

choices.text: Change log.
Stakeholder register.
Scope management plan.
Requirements management plan.

text: A project has been closed and customer care needs to measure customer satisfaction with the deliverables.nnWhat should be done next?
explanation:
After the project is closed, it is important to evaluate the project outputs and customer satisfaction to ensure that the objectives and delivery quality are achieved. Evaluating project outputs and reviewing client feedback helps to understand strengths and weaknesses, and provides a basis for improving future projects.

 Because it reflects the performance and output evaluation step based on the customer's feedback after delivery.

- Why are other options wrong?
- Negotiating an additional contract that is not related to the satisfaction measurement.
- A meeting to discuss lessons learned is important but comes after the customer satisfaction assessment.
- The closing review for each stage is part of the internal processes and is not related to the customer satisfaction measurement.

choices.text: Negotiate additional contract with customer for similar service.
Schedule meeting with stakeholders and customer to discuss lessons learned.
Evaluate project deliverables and review customer feedback documents.
Audit project success by reviewing closing documentation for each project phase.

text: A customer is concerned that the current project deliverable will not fulfill stated project requirements. What could be done to alleviate customer concerns?
explanation:
To alleviate the customer's concern about the outputs, it is important to review the previously agreed acceptance criteria and ensure that the outputs meet these criteria. Involving the product owner in this review enhances communication and confirms understanding between the team and the customer.

- Because reviewing the acceptance criteria with the product owner helps to address concerns directly and effectively.

- Why are other options wrong?
- Reminding the customer of the requirements may not calm his anxiety if acceptance is not actually verified.
- Recording anxiety as a risk needs a response plan and does not directly relieve anxiety.
- Managing anxiety while reviewing each exit is a task but without reviewing the acceptance criteria may be insufficient.

choices.text: Schedule a meeting to remind the customer of requirements previously communicated to the team.
Document the customer's concern as a risk in the risk register and plan accordingly.
Manage the concern at the review of each deliverable with the customer.
Ask a product owner to review the acceptance criteria previously discussed with the customer.

text: A project manager is working with stakeholders to identify the steps that must be completed as part of a task. The project manager needs to be able to verify that team members have completed all the steps required when performing a frequently performed task.nnWhat should the project manager use?
explanation:
In the case of repetitive tasks that require specific steps to be performed on a regular basis, a checklist is used to ensure that all steps are completed correctly and regularly.

-The checklist is a simple and effective tool to ensure that all steps in the repetitive task are completed, reducing errors and increasing accuracy.

- Why are other options wrong?
- A flowchart used to visualize the flow of processes and not to verify that steps have been completed.
- The histogram is used to analyze data and not to follow steps.
- Facilitation is a session leadership technique, not a task tracking tool.

choices.text: Flowchart
Checklist
Histogram
Facilitation

text: A project team has not been performing user acceptance tests on a deliverable because the product has been working as expected in other projects. However, after implementation, the product is not operational.nnWhat should the project manager do to identify the source of the problem?
explanation:
When a bug appears after implementation even though no user acceptance test has been conducted, the project manager should use root cause analysis to accurately determine the root cause of the problem and work to fix it.

- Root cause analysis focuses on identifying the true causes of the problem rather than just treating the symptoms.

- Why are other options wrong?
- A review of the quality metrics document may not reveal the true cause.
- The scatter scheme is used for variable relationships and not for analyzing the causes of the problem.
- The audit focuses on verifying compliance with procedures but is not a root cause analysis tool.

choices.text: Review the quality metrics document.
Develop a scatter diagram.
Conduct a root cause analysis.
Perform an audit.

text: A manufacturing company receives customer complaints that a product is defective. A project sponsor has said that these complaints might be outliers.nnWhat should the project manager use to investigate the cause and quantity of defects in this product?
explanation:
A histogram is a statistical tool used to display the distribution of data, such as the number and types of defects, which helps the project manager understand the prevalence and pattern of defects.

- The frequency graph displays the quantity and types of defects in a visual way that helps to analyze them accurately.

- Why are other options wrong?
- Flowcharts are used to illustrate the flow of operations and not to analyze quantitative data.
- The convergence chart is used to organize ideas and problems but is not a quantitative analysis tool for defects.
- The control diagram is used to monitor processes over time and not to directly determine the number or causes of defects.

choices.text: Flowcharts
Affinity diagram
Control chart
Histogram

text: A company needs to compare customer satisfaction results with organizations that are industry leaders in customer care. What should the project manager use to measure performance?
explanation:
Benchmarking is the process of measuring the performance of a company or project and comparing it with industry best practices or with leading competitors to improve performance.

- Benchmarking helps identify performance gaps and achieve continuous improvement.

- Why are other options wrong?
- Mind mapping is a tool for organizing ideas, not measuring performance.
- Interviews are used to collect information and are not a performance comparison tool.
- Convergence charts are used to organize information and not to analyze performance.

choices.text: Benchmarking
Mind mapping
Interviews
Affinity diagrams

text: A project manager is conducting product testing and has identified several quality issues. The project manager wants to identify and address the root cause.nnWhat should the project manager do?
explanation:
When the project manager encounters frequent quality issues, using the fish chart (Ishikawa/Fishbone Diagram) helps analyze the root cause of the problem.

-Why the right choice?
Fish chart is used to identify and analyze the root causes of a problem by dividing possible causes into categories such as equipment, processes, people, materials, environment, etc.

- Why are other options wrong?
- The convergence diagram is used to organize ideas and not to identify root causes.
- The frequency graph shows the distribution of the frequency of problems rather than cause-and-effect relationships.
- The matrix diagram is used to show relationships between different elements, but it is not used for causal analysis.

choices.text: Analyze the results of an affinity diagram.
Analyze the results of a histogram.
Analyze the results of a fishbone diagram.
Analyze the results of a matrix diagram.

text:
You are the project manager on a project delivered by a Scrum team. The project sponsors are not familiar with the Scrum framework and were invited to attend the first Sprint Review. They ask you to describe the scope of this event.

Which of the following are the goals of the Sprint Review? (Choose 3)
explanation:
A Sprint Review meeting is a formal event held at the end of each sprint to inspect what has been achieved, get feedback from stakeholders, and determine the next direction based on progress.

-  Presenting what the team has accomplished and comparing it to the goal of the sprint is one of the goals of the meeting.
- Collaborating with stakeholders to get their feedback helps improve the product and plan for the next sprint.
- Reviewing progress towards the overall product goal ensures that the work aligns with the project vision.

- Why are other options wrong?
- Analysis of team performance is done in the Sprint Retrospective  meeting and not in the Sprint Review.
- Discussing the team's personal challenges is not a goal of the formal meeting, but can be discussed in separate internal sessions.

choices.text: Demonstrate what was completed during the Sprint and discuss how it meets the Sprint Goal.
Collaborate with stakeholders to gather feedback and discuss the next steps.
Review progress toward the overall product or project goal.
Analyze team performance and identify internal process improvements.
Discuss personal challenges team members faced during the Sprint.

text: A project manager needs to close out a project and does not have time to update the lessons learned register.nnWhat could be a consequence of this failure to act?
explanation:
Updating the record of lessons learned is an essential part of the project closure phase. This log helps organizations improve performance and avoid repeat errors in future projects.

- Failure to update this record may result in missing out on valuable opportunities to avoid similar issues later, losing the organization the opportunity to learn and continuously improve.

- Why are other options wrong?
- Work performance data collected during implementation and is not directly related to project closure.
- The project management plan is in the early stages and does not occur at the end of the project.
- Failure to update lessons learned does not directly lead to stakeholder refusal to participate in subsequent projects.

choices.text: Work performance data would be incomplete and unavailable for analysis.
Opportunities to prevent similar problems in future projects could be missed.
The project management plan could be inaccurate and misleading.
Key stakeholders would refuse to engage in future projects.

text: Project completion will be delayed because an essential component will not be delivered on time. What should the project manager do?
explanation:
When faced with a potential delay, the project manager must first assess the impact of that delay on the schedule, cost, scope, and quality of the project.

- Assess the impact before taking any action to ensure that the decision will be based on careful analysis of risks and consequences, not on an ill-considered reaction.

- Why are other options wrong?
- Consulting and adjusting before understanding the impact may lead to ill-considered decisions.
- Reviewing the scope plan does not directly address the problem of delay.
- Verification of penalties is a subsequent step after the impact assessment and not the first action.

choices.text: Consult with stakeholders and revise the project schedule to reflect the delay.
Review the scope management plan to understand how acceptance of project deliverables could still be obtained.
Check the procurement contract for penalties that can be imposed on the supplier of the component.
Evaluate the impact of the delay before deciding what actions are necessary.

text: A project manager needs to close a project phase. What step should project manager take?
explanation:
Closing the phase of the project requires making sure that its objectives are achieved as planned. Therefore, reviewing the project management plan helps to ensure that all required activities have been completed and that the outputs meet the criteria.

-Review the project management plan shows whether the phase goals have actually been achieved, which is the essential step before moving on to the next stage or closing.

- Why are other options wrong?
- Agreeing on outputs may be part of acceptance, but it is not enough to close the entire phase.
- Comparing outputs to the project charter is important but it is about closing the project as a whole, not just the phase.
- Reviewing assumptions and constraints is broader than just staged closing.

choices.text: Ensure deliverables have full buy-in according to decision process established for phase.
Compare project deliverables with project charter and request customer sign off.
Review high-level strategic and operational assumptions and constraints with stakeholders.
Review project management plan to ensure phase objectives have been met.

text: A project was cancelled during its initiation phase due to lack of adequate resources. What should the project manager do?
explanation:
When canceling a project at any stage, it is important to follow the formal regulatory procedures to close the project in an orderly manner. Referring to the closing guidelines ensures that all required steps are met.

- Company's project closure guidelines contain the procedures and policies to be followed to ensure the formal and proper completion of the project.

- Why are other options wrong?
- Informing the team is important, but it is part of the communication plan and not enough alone.
- Performing a risk analysis is not useful at this stage after the cancellation decision has been made.
- Reassigning resources should take place after the project is officially closed, not as a first priority.

choices.text: Inform all team members according to guidelines in the communications management plan.
Refer to the company's project closure guidelines.
Perform a risk analysis to determine the impact of terminating the project.
Reassign all resources and reallocate budget.

text: A new project stakeholder is identified who has interest in, but little authority or influence on, the project. How should the project manager handle this stakeholder?
explanation:
In stakeholder analysis, they are categorized based on level of authority, influence and interest. For stakeholders who have a high interest but low influence or authority, the most appropriate strategy is to 'Keep Informed'.

- Providing them with information when needed is a practical way to satisfy their interest while avoiding spending resources on involving them unnecessarily, commensurate with their limited impact.

- Why are other options wrong?
- 'Working closely with him' is an approach used for high-impact stakeholders.
- 'Follow-up and response' is suitable for those with medium impact.
- 'Involve him in periodic updates' is more suitable for high-impact and high-interest stakeholders.

choices.text: Provide information to the stakeholder as needed.
Work closely with the stakeholder to proactively address their concerns.
Keep track of the stakeholder and respond to their needs.
Include the stakeholder on standard updates and keep them satisfied.

text: A project manager recognizes the need to improve team dynamics and knowledge sharing during a megaproject.nnWhat should the project manager do?
explanation:
In complex and large projects, the need for effective collaboration and knowledge sharing increases. One of the best approaches is to facilitate open discussions within the team.

- This helps address organizational or individual problems before they escalate.

- Why are other options wrong?
- Organizing skills sessions is good, but it does not guarantee dialogue or addressing challenges.
- Assigning new members to difficult tasks without support can impair performance.
- The orientation program may be effective, but the quickest and most comprehensive solution is a group dialogue in which everyone participates.

choices.text: Conduct knowledge-sharing sessions where experienced team members present their expertise.
Assign junior team members tasks that push their skill level and offer minimal support.
Implement a formal mentoring program with structured goals and regular meetings.
Facilitate open team discussions to identify and address individual challenges and concerns.

text: A project manager compiling a list of project stakeholders discovers an interested stakeholder with little to no authority. How should they manage this stakeholder?
explanation:
In stakeholder management, the 'power versus interest' model is used to classify them. Stakeholders with high interest and low authority are advised to keep them informed.

- Because this party has an interest in the project, they should be informed of what is going on without having to involve them deeply, which keeps communication flowing without draining resources.

- Why are other options wrong?
- 'Keep it satisfied' is used for those with high authority and low interest.
- 'Close management' applies to those with high influence and high interest.
- 'Monitor' is suitable for those with low interest and authority.

choices.text: Keep satisfied.
Manage closely.
Monitor.
Keep informed.

text: A project stakeholder has been missing scheduled facilitation workshops and has delegated assigned tasks to another member of the stakeholder community. What should the project manager do to engage this stakeholder?
explanation:
When there is a weakness in a stakeholder's engagement, the first step is to check whether their roles and responsibilities are clear and understandable. Charter review helps to redefine each party's obligations.

-Reviewroles as defined in the project charter highlights stakeholder responsibilities and resets expectations.

- Why are other options wrong?
- Explaining the differences in tasks does not solve the underlying problem.
- Asking the program manager to intervene is an unnecessary escalation at this stage.
- Pairing him with a team member as an appropriate mentor in case of poor competence, not poor commitment.

choices.text: Review with the stakeholder the roles and responsibilities of everyone involved as specified in the project charter.
Explain to the stakeholder the differences among the tasks assigned to each project team member.
Ask the program manager to brief this stakeholder and to require the stakeholder's attendance at all relevant meetings.
Pair the stakeholder with a more experienced team member who can act as a mentor.

text: While executing a project that is nearly behind schedule, a project manager must commission a new piece of equipment. Two local parties who will be impacted by this commission ask that the project be stopped immediately because they were not given an opportunity to provide project approval.nnHow would implement a stakeholder engagement plan have helped the project manager avoid this situation?
explanation:
The stakeholder engagement plan aims to identify all parties involved in the project and identify strategies for their inclusion in a timely manner. If local parties had been identified as stakeholders in the plan, they would have been included in official communication channels and received the necessary information to express their opinions or agreement in advance.

-  Because the inclusion of affected parties in the communication plan within the stakeholder engagement plan ensures that they are informed and engaged.

- Why are other options wrong?
 - The use of conflict management techniques assumes the existence of an actual conflict, not a preventive means.
 - Their signature on the project charter is not always required, and may not be possible.
 - Negotiation techniques are applied only after communication, and are not a substitute for their inclusion in advance.

choices.text: By using the conflict management techniques described in the plan, the project manager could have gotten approval from the local parties.
Including the local parties in the plan would have ensured their sign-off and approval of the project charter.
By understanding the local parties' expectations, the project manager could have used appropriate negotiating techniques to engage them.
By identifying the local parties as stakeholders, they would have been included in relevant communications.

text: A key stakeholder refuses to sign off on a product because it does not meet the expectations outlined in the project scope. What should the project manager have done to avoid this situation?
explanation:
Stakeholder engagement management requires their continuous involvement throughout the project lifecycle, especially key stakeholders who influence the final acceptance of outputs. Gathering continuous feedback ensures that outputs are aligned with their expectations and that the scope or design is adjusted when needed.

- Because collecting opinions on an ongoing basis allows for early detection of gaps between expectations and scope.

- Why are other options wrong?
 - Risk assessment for threats or opportunities, not acceptance expectations.
 - Conflict management techniques are used when an actual problem occurs.
 - Involve only in the testing phase too late to modify the scope or product.

choices.text: Solicited stakeholder feedback throughout the life cycle of the project.
Conducted risk assessments based on the stakeholder's expectations.
Implemented conflict management techniques during sign-off.
Involved the key stakeholder during the testing phase.

text: A project schedule requires that two teams work simultaneously on separate parts of a complex project. The two parts of the project are dependent on each other. The project manager needs to ensure there are no conflicts when the outputs from the two teams are combined.nnWhat should the project manager do to manage any potential conflicts first?
explanation:
When different teams are working on interconnected parts of a project, regular coordination is essential to avoid conflicts when merging outputs. Weekly meetings provide a platform to exchange progress, challenges, technical and integration developments between teams.

-Organizing weekly meetings between the two teams allows continuous follow-up and identification of any problems or differences early.

- Why are other options wrong?
- Prioritizing the critical path does not resolve conflicts between teams, but rather about scheduling.
- Reviewing lessons learned is important, but it is not enough as an initial measure to manage conflicts in real time.
- Stakeholder engagement is beneficial for public support, but does not address day-to-day technical coordination between teams.

choices.text: Set up weekly meetings between the teams to monitor each other's work.
Prioritize conflict resolution for the part of the project that is on the critical path.
Review the lessons learned register to anticipate potential conflicts and plan their resolution.
Engage project stakeholders to ensure their support through any conflicts as they arise.

text: A project manager is developing a project charter, but a key stakeholder is failing to provide information about the expected project benefits. Why should the project manager meet with the project sponsor about this issue?
explanation:
The project sponsor is the executive officer who has the authority to support the project at the political and strategic level. When a project manager faces resistance or lack of cooperation from an important stakeholder, the project sponsor can intervene to address policy issues or urge parties to cooperate.

- Because the project sponsor has influence within the organization to address internal issues that hinder the progress of the project, especially when it relates to vital information such as expected benefits.

- Why are other options wrong?
- Managing tacit knowledge is not the primary role of the sponsor.
- Change in the stakeholder community is done in collaboration with the stakeholders themselves, not through the Change Board (CCB).
- Disciplinary actions are not the responsibility of the project sponsor, but usually the responsibility of human resources.

choices.text: The project sponsor is the key person responsible for managing both tacit and explicit project knowledge.
The project sponsor is the party who can address internal political and strategic issues that can affect project quality.
The project sponsor can request that the change control board (CCB) make a change in the stakeholder community.
Disciplinary actions regarding stakeholders are managed by the project sponsor.

text: An intern is replacing a critical resource midway through a sprint. To help the intern get up to speed, the project manager assigns a senior engineer in the team as the intern's mentor.
