Lead: Okay. We have been through this for the last four sprints and need to resolve it. After sprint 3, you blamed a faulty technical setup for the delay but we learned that was not accurate. Do you think you can give us more realistic estimates next time?
Team Member: Yes, I was wrong. I thought I was providing realistic estimates but realized after three sprints that my method must be flawed.
Lead: Do you want to do a planning session together so we can figure out a better way?
Team Member: Yes, that would be helpful. I know that my delay is causing stress on the team. Thanks!
Which two components of emotional intelligence (EI) has this team member just realized? (Choose 2)
explanation: This team member has just completed an accurate self-assessment thanks to the coaching session. This is the step when the team member declares that “I realize. . .” The next step is self-management, which happens when we accept responsibility for our actions. When the team member admitted to wrongly blaming something else after sprint 3, they accepted responsibility and demonstrated self-managing behavior.

choices.text: Self-control
Self-discovery
Self-assessment
Self-definition
Self-management

text:
A project manager meets frequently with their company’s human resources (HR) partner. Several project team members wear T-shirts on Fridays, which others in the organization consider controversial. The team members are allowed to wear these T-shirts, but there have been numerous complaints throughout the company.
What should the project manager do first?
explanation: Understanding the cultural contexts of the organization, its larger culture(s), and the individuals involved is essential in choosing the right course of action. Since the team is permitted to wear the T-shirts, the best course of action is to coach the team members on how to be more self-aware so they can understand how their actions may be causing others distress, even though the T-shirts are allowed. This option is more transformational than any of the others and will provide better, longer-lasting results.

choices.text: Caution the team members about wearing the T-shirts to work.
Coach the team members on self-awareness.
Continue meeting with the human resources (HR) partner.
Find out why the team members are wearing these T-shirts.

text:
A project is more than halfway finished when a new project manager joins the team. The project manager notices the team has not been conducting retrospectives at the end of every iteration. Instead, they are conducting them after the release, which is every 6 months. When the project manager addresses this during the all-hands meeting, the team responds that retrospectives are a waste of time because nothing changes.
What should the project manager do in this situation?
explanation: Coaching and facilitating retrospectives (C) addresses the root cause of the team's resistance to retrospectives—perceived lack of value—and offers a constructive, agile-aligned solution. Rather than merely enforcing process compliance (B) or vaguely improving morale (D), the project manager takes an active role in coaching the team and facilitating retrospectives in a way that demonstrates their impact on value delivery and quality improvement. This aligns with agile principles of continuous improvement and empowers the team to see retrospectives not as a formality, but as a tool for meaningful change. Practicing servant leadership (A) is important but too broad to directly resolve the specific issue of ineffective or absent retrospectives.

choices.text: Practice servant leadership.
Explain to the team that retrospectives are part of being agile.
Coach and facilitate retrospectives for value delivery and quality.
Suggest team-building exercises to improve team culture.

text:
An agile team working on a project requires a team member with a specialized skill. Because of time limitations, the agile team has two options: borrow a part-time team member from another department or use an independent contractor. The eight team members discuss the options but are unable to reach an agreement. The vote is 50/50, and both options have positive benefits as well as risks.
What should the project team do next?
explanation: A multicriteria decision analysis (MCDA) is a structured decision-making technique that helps teams evaluate complex options based on defined criteria such as cost, risk, availability, and impact. In this scenario, the team is evenly split between two viable choices, each with pros and cons. Rather than relying on a simple majority or deferring the decision (C), guiding the team through an MCDA allows for an objective, transparent process that supports collaboration and aligns with agile principles. Option A is inappropriate because secondary risks are not the only consideration, and option D undermines team empowerment and shared ownership.

choices.text: Review the risk register and choose the option without a secondary risk.
Guide the team through a multicriteria decision analysis.
Wait until the next retrospective and ask again.
Ask the product owner to decide.

text:
In Q3 of the following year, a virtual team will travel to a work site and work as a colocated team for 6 weeks to transition a project to the customer. One team member, whose role is critical to the transition, is getting married during Q3 but has not told anyone until now. This team member requested a 3-week leave right before the planned team travel. 
What should the project manager do?
explanation: This scenario shows a typical part of working life, and the best response is to mitigate this team member's absence as a single point of failure by asking someone else on the team to expand their skill set. With time to plan for resource coverage, there should be no delay or disruption! While rejecting the request is a possible answer, it is an overreach of authority and an overreaction. The project manager should definitely congratulate the team member on their upcoming marriage.

choices.text: Ask another team member to job shadow this team member as a contingency.
Reject the request because this team member's role is critical.
Plan for the risk of a delayed transition because of this team member’s absence.
Replace this team member now to avoid disruption the following year.

text:
An agile project team is working in an environment experiencing significant upheaval. Team members are stressed and not performing well, but the work must continue.  
What should the project team do?
explanation: If work must continue, then the answer is finding a way to focus on the work. Extending deadlines or pretending nothing is wrong can be risky. Examining project closure options may be a bit drastic at this stage.

choices.text: Support the scrum master in focusing the team on desired outcomes.
Ask the product owner to add time to the schedule.
Continue working as usual.
Examine project closure or cancellation options.

text:
A project team member in a company with a projectized organizational structure is experiencing significant challenges in their personal life. The team is not aware of this—they only see mistakes and missed deadlines. The team is in the middle of an iteration and this team member’s latest mistake has caused a major issue.
How should the team lead respond in this situation?
explanation: Team performance is the focus of an agile team. If a team member is underperforming, the team lead should work with them as much as possible to improve performance.

choices.text: Meet with the team member and provide feedback.
Replace the team member.
Discipline the team member.
Consult with the team member’s functional manager.

text:
A product team has completed eight of 10 planned iterations for a streamlining project. While refining the backlog for iteration nine, the product owner learns about a massive, company-wide budget change and sends this email:
Dear streamlining project team,
The budget change announced yesterday will impact our project. I may need to reprioritize some of our planned work.
How should the team lead respond?
explanation: Reprioritizing the backlog (A) reflects the agile principle of adapting to change while maintaining momentum. The product owner’s message signals a likely shift in priorities due to budget constraints, but it does not instruct the team to stop work. The team lead should respond proactively by recommending a backlog reprioritization to ensure the remaining iterations focus on the highest-value work under the new budget conditions. This keeps the team productive and aligned with evolving business needs. Option B delays action unnecessarily, Option C steps outside the team lead’s role, and Option D is premature and not aligned with agile practices of responding to change constructively.

choices.text: Recommend reprioritizing the backlog and still run a few more iterations.
Wait for the product owner’s decision.
Contact the finance department to find out more about the budget cut.
Disband the team so they have time to find new assignments.

text:
User testing on the last product release revealed low-user interest in certain features that required a significant effort to develop. Team members feel demoralized and want to help ensure their future efforts are worthwhile. Success in the next iteration is critical, because the competitor product is gaining market share.
How should the project team respond?
explanation: Suggesting the product owner prioritize the desired end user features and engage stakeholders (B) emphasizes the importance of aligning the product development process with the needs and priorities of the end users and stakeholders. By suggesting that the product owner prioritize the desired end user features and engage stakeholders, the project team can ensure that the features developed in the next iteration are valuable and relevant to the target audience. This approach helps in addressing the issue of low-user interest by focusing on features that are more likely to meet user needs and expectations. Engaging stakeholders also provides valuable insights and feedback, which can guide the team in making informed decisions about feature prioritization.

choices.text: Review the product roadmap and brainstorm how to better understand the product vision.
Suggest the product owner prioritize the desired end user features and engage stakeholders.
Focus on creating a better definition of ready for the user stories.
Perform a stakeholder analysis to find subject matter experts who can guide the backlog value ranking process.

text:
A major international sporting event will be broadcast live on every continent. To prepare for the event, a project manager arranges professional media training for key members of the project team and stakeholders. Stakeholder A, who is outspoken and extremely active in the media, is not taking the training class seriously. The facilitator reports the issue via email, stating: “I can’t work with this trainee anymore!”
What should the project manager do next?
explanation: Meeting with Stakeholder A to understand (D) demonstrates the project manager’s responsibility to engage stakeholders constructively and collaboratively, especially when issues arise. Rather than jumping to conclusions, assigning blame, or taking punitive action, the project manager should meet with stakeholder A to understand their perspective and identify how the training experience can be improved. This approach preserves the working relationship, promotes mutual respect, and supports the goal of ensuring all participants are prepared for a high-visibility event. Options A and B avoid addressing the root cause, while option C risks escalating tension without first seeking understanding.

choices.text: Continue the training and log the issue with stakeholder A.
Attend the next session to confirm the facilitator’s reported issue.
Coach stakeholder A about their attitude and redo their training.
Meet with stakeholder A to understand how to improve the training.

text:
A project to train kitchen personnel in process efficiencies for a restaurant franchise includes a small four-member project team. It is essential this team has a broad understanding of the franchise’s business processes so they can create training that delivers the efficiencies required across the business.
Which team member already has T-shaped skills that would be beneficial to this project?
explanation: The T-shaped team member is the team lead for finance and operations. Because of their experience running this type of business, this team member has the greatest depth and breadth of relevant experience among the four team members.

choices.text: Project manager with 30 years of experience leading business development projects
Training specialist with 10 years of experience in menu development
Team member, and also a scrum master, with 5 years of experience leading teams
Team lead for finance and operations who once owned and operated a franchise

text:
A team member has a very varied skill set and performs their work well. This team member has been allocated to many different roles during their work history with the company. For this reason, the team member states: “I feel like I am put on projects randomly. I am not getting anywhere, and the company does not value my work.”
Which action should the project manager take next?
explanation: Meeting with the team member to discuss career progression demonstrates leadership through active listening, empathy, and collaborative planning. By meeting with the team member to discuss their concerns and co-create a career progression plan, the project manager validates the individual’s feelings and provides a clear path forward—reinforcing engagement, motivation, and alignment with both personal and organizational goals.

choices.text: Remind the team member of the value of cross-functional teams and help them find a suitable mentor for career development.
Reassure the team member of their value as a T-shaped team member who can contribute a diverse skill set to the team.
Meet with the team member to discuss career progression and agree on an action plan.
Urge the team member to earn as many certifications as possible.

text:
A project team member on an agile team is consistently missing deadlines, creating bottlenecks for the rest of the team.
What action can the Scrum master take to support the team member and improve team performance?
explanation: Engaging the team member and discussing their challenges is part of the Scrum Master’s role as a servant leader and coach, supporting individual team members while promoting overall team performance. When a team member is consistently missing deadlines, the root cause may involve personal challenges, misunderstandings, or systemic issues. By directly engaging the team member in a one-on-one conversation, the Scrum Master can identify obstacles, offer support, and collaborate on solutions. This approach fosters trust and accountability without blame. Options A and D may be useful later but are premature without first understanding the issue, and B risks singling out the individual publicly, which may harm team morale.

choices.text: Enroll the team member in time management training.
The team member should speak first in daily coordination meetings.
The scrum master should engage the team member and discuss their challenges.
The next retrospective agenda should include a self-evaluation exercise led by the scrum master.

text:
A company initiates a project to replace aging infrastructure by adopting experimental green technology. The project team is having initial conversations about how to approach the project and why the decision-makers feel this approach is necessary.
Which two assets will be helpful to the team? (Choose 2)
explanation: The most helpful assets to a newly forming team on a project with high risk are the business case, an initial risk assessment, and the team charter. These documents state why the business needs or wants the project; they help determine the resources needed, the inherent risk in undertaking the project, and the terms of working together. The benefit-cost analysis helps compare the proposed benefits to the costs—so this is useful later. The benefits management plan should start to be formed at this stage; this summary of what the expected benefits are from updating the infrastructure and adopting the new technology, as well as how they will be delivered to and measured by the business, will be key to creating it.

choices.text: Ground rules
Business case
Initial risk assessment
Cost-benefit analysis
Stakeholder register

text: A product owner is reviewing notes from the latest stakeholder meeting and discussing proposed changes to a project with the project team. Which two notes should be considered potential changes to the product backlog? (Choose 2)
explanation: Answers B and C both represent potential additions or modifications to the product backlog. In B, the team member's idea written on a sticky note may represent a new feature, enhancement, or improvement; even informal suggestions are valid backlog candidates if they provide value. In C, the unprioritized user story from stakeholder B introduces revised quality requirements, which are a form of functional or non-functional change and should be reviewed and refined as part of backlog grooming. In contrast, A refers to a change within the current iteration, which is typically resisted in agile to maintain focus. D describes a managed issue, not a change request, and E involves corrective work that likely already exists in the backlog.

choices.text: Recommendation from stakeholder M to change a task in the current iteration
Team member wrote their new idea on a yellow sticky note and put it on a kanban board
Unprioritized user story—stakeholder B wants new and improved quality requirements
Quality issue detected—but the team has this under control
Bug fix from a previous iteration

text:
A hotel chain wants to improve their customer loyalty program by increasing the number of returning guests by 35%. The project manager hears about two strong stakeholder opinions:
•	Stakeholder J suggests the sales teams focus on the top 10 corporate clients and incentivize them toward exclusive use of this hotel chain.
•	Stakeholder M suggests improving the quality of their airport locations, which already has many returning guests. Stakeholder M also insists the chain cannot compete in larger markets, so the strategy stakeholder J suggests will fail.
In a dramatic escalation, stakeholder M emails the project manager and entire leadership team accusing stakeholder J of bias. 
What should the project manager do first?
explanation: The problem in this scenario is stakeholder M’s challenging behavior. Accusing stakeholder J of bias could be perceived as a personal attack, but it could also be a very awkward way of stating a fact. We know that conflict is in a mature stage (“contest” in the Leas model) and must be handled right away. Trying one more time to determine an initial scope is the best action because it focuses on the solution, not the personal battle; however, if neither coaching nor mediation work, escalation may become the only option. It is likely not within any project manager’s authority to remove stakeholders from projects, even though this would calm the situation.

choices.text: Facilitate conflict resolution between the two stakeholders and determine an initial scope that satisfies both.
Coach stakeholder M about professional behavior and ask them to apologize to stakeholder J.
Escalate this issue to human resources (HR).
Meet with stakeholder M to understand their side of the argument.

text:
A product owner has created many epics and has started breaking them down into user stories. These user stories fulfill the definition of ready. During iteration planning, the product owner leaves halfway through the meeting.
What should happen next?
explanation: The team should continue where the product owner stopped and complete the activity, which began as a collaborative exercise with the product owner. The team can decompose the user stories into tasks, estimate them before putting them on the sprint or kanban board, then continue this work for the remainder of the iteration planning meeting.

choices.text: The team lead should draft the remaining acceptance criteria before starting the iteration.
The iteration planning should end after the estimate and team commitment.
The product owner should present the committed user stories with the key stakeholders before the iteration starts.
The team should decompose the user stories into tasks.

text:
At the beginning of a customer service improvement project, two stakeholders are noted as “resistant” on the stakeholder engagement assessment matrix:
•	A finance executive who says the cost of the project is too high.
•	The customer care team that wants better salaries and working conditions.
All other stakeholders support the project.
After months of difficult negotiations, the customer care stakeholder group is now noted as “neutral,” although final agreements must be signed; this is ongoing and will take significant time and effort. The finance executive continues to state that the cost of the project is too high.
What should the project manager do next?
explanation: Meeting with the finance executive to clarify their concerns (A) demonstrates the project manager’s responsibility to engage directly with stakeholders—especially those who remain resistant—in a constructive and solution-focused manner. The finance executive's continued concerns about cost pose a potential risk to project buy-in and long-term success. Meeting with the executive allows the project manager to actively listen, clarify misunderstandings, and possibly uncover alternatives or trade-offs. This approach maintains transparency and trust while reinforcing stakeholder engagement best practices. Option B assumes alignment without addressing the finance executive’s resistance; C delegates a leadership responsibility; and D is impersonal and unlikely to resolve the conflict effectively.

choices.text: Meet with the finance executive to clarify their concerns.
Focus on negotiating the final agreements for the customer care stakeholder group at a cost the finance executive may accept.
Ask the business analyst to explain or justify the cost of the salary increases to the finance executive.
Send an email to all stakeholders, stating the problem and urging them to find a solution.

text:
An organization’s leadership wants to enhance employee welfare by providing childcare services and wants these services in place as soon as possible. The project team needs to decide how to implement the new service and has a brainstorming session.
Which two questions should the team explore as they initiate the project? (Choose 2)
explanation: To get this critical project started right away, the team should decide on the composition of the implementation team and how to provision the services mandated by leadership as quickly and effectively as possible. Decisions about the strategic importance and benefits have already been made, so we can assume this is why the project has executive approval. The team can explore eligibility and the types of care offered after these decisions have been made.

choices.text: Is this part of the company’s growth strategy?
How will the company determine who is eligible for the services?
How many team members and which skills will be required to implement the services?
Will the services be contracted out or maintained by company employees?
What are the benefits of these services?

text:
An agile team is deployed to create a workable solution for helping a region with a contaminated water supply. The team is working with the government, contractors, and local residents to resolve the problem. The product owner is trying to determine the urgency of the issue.
What should the product owner do next?
explanation: The customers in this project are the local stakeholders. The team is responsible for learning about their needs and desired outcomes. The cost of available technologies and number of people affected will determine the course of action, but the required sense of urgency can only be known by asking those affected.

choices.text: Research the market and make a list of available technologies.
Work with the regional stakeholders to find out how much they are affected.
Determine the costs of a few solutions.
Determine the contamination source.

text: A project team is updating a stakeholder engagement assessment matrix. Which three labels indicate a stakeholder is actively engaged in a project? (Choose 3)
explanation:
The five labels typically used to describe stakeholder engagement are: unaware, resistant/detractor, neutral, supportive, and leading/champion. Of these, the active ones are: resistant, supportive, and leading or champion. Resistant or detractor stakeholders are not supportive of the project and may try to harm, undermine, or dissuade others from supporting. All are active ways of engaging. Supportive and leading stakeholders play a supporting or leading role in the project objectives, being advocates, or helping facilitate tasks, for example. The labels of neutral and unaware indicate stakeholder indifference, ignorance, or inactivity.

We use these labels and conduct stakeholder analysis to move stakeholders from current to desired levels of engagement and ensure the stakeholders are supportive, or at least not actively unsupportive, of the project objectives.

choices.text: Unaware
Supportive
Neutral
Resistant
Leading

text:
A project manager is observing a work site and notices several potential hazards that could endanger worker and equipment welfare and impact the project timeline and budget. The project manager schedules a risk planning meeting with the project team and asks the team to identify and analyze potential risks and develop appropriate response strategies. 

Which action should the project manager take?
explanation:
When a project manager identifies potential hazards on a job site, they should document and manage these risks to ensure the safety of workers and successful completion of the project. Developing a risk register to document identified risks, their analyses, and planned responses is the correct answer, because developing a risk register is a fundamental step in risk management.

While prioritizing risks by impact is important, it is only one part of the risk management process. Without documenting the risks and their responses, the project manager may miss critical details and fail to communicate effectively with the team. Assigning risks to team members for resolution is part of the risk response process but should be done after the risks have been documented and analyzed. This ensures the team members understand the risks and planned responses. Delaying the analysis and decision-making process can lead to unmanaged risks escalating and causing more significant issues. It is essential to address risks promptly and continuously monitor them.

choices.text: Prioritize the risks by impact from minor to major risks and plan for the major risks first.
Develop a risk register to document identified risks, their analyses, and planned responses.
Identify all risks and assign them to project team members for resolution.
Make some initial decisions about the risks, then wait 2 weeks to reassess before committing to a strategy.

text: Which three stakeholder or organizational characteristics do project professionals consider when evaluating or assessing the potential impact of risks? (Choose 3)
explanation:
Tolerances refer to the degree of variability that stakeholders are willing to accept in the project. Understanding tolerances helps in determining how much deviation from the project management plan is acceptable before corrective actions are needed. Thresholds are specific points or levels at which a risk becomes unacceptable and triggers a response. Knowing the thresholds helps in identifying when a risk should be addressed to prevent it from impacting the project negatively. Appetites refer to the level of risk an organization or stakeholder is willing to take. Understanding risk appetites helps in aligning the risk management approach with the overall risk-taking philosophy of the organization.

While the way of working can influence how risks are managed, it is not a primary characteristic considered when evaluating the potential impact of risks. It is more related to the processes and methodologies used in the project. Organizational hierarchy can affect decision-making and communication, but it is not directly related to assessing the potential impact of risks. Organizational hierarchy is about the structure and roles within the organization.

choices.text: Tolerances
Thresholds
Way of working
Organizational hierarchy
Appetites

text: A project team is using a predictive planning approach to control the timeline and budget and an agile development approach to iteratively design a product. What is the role of the project manager?
explanation:
This project team is using a hybrid approach, combining predictive planning elements with an agile execution strategy. The project manager provides high-level management direction and coordination, ensuring alignment between the predictive and agile approaches.

Coaching the agile team to strictly follow the predictive approach contradicts the principles of an agile approach, which emphasizes flexibility and adaptability. Delegating all planning responsibilities to the agile team and focusing solely on budget control is incorrect, because the project manager should oversee both planning and budget control, ensuring the predictive and agile approaches are integrated effectively. Focusing on delivering the project on time while allowing the team to control the design development is incorrect. While focusing on timely delivery is important, the project manager should also ensure the predictive and agile approaches are aligned and coordinated, rather than allowing the team to control design development independently.

choices.text: Coach the agile team to ensure they follow the predictive plan strictly.
Provide high-level management direction and coordination, ensuring alignment between the predictive and agile approaches.
Delegate planning responsibilities to the agile team and focus on budget control.
Focus on delivering the project on time while allowing the team to control the design development.

text: Which two statements reflect how a project manager should manage conflict in a team? (Choose 2)
explanation:
A project manager should recognize that conflict is a regular part of team culture and should document the outcomes of conflicts in lessons learned. This approach helps in managing conflicts effectively and provides valuable insights for future projects. Conflict is a natural occurrence in any team environment and can be a sign of healthy engagement and diverse perspectives. Recognizing that conflict is a regular part of team culture helps in managing it effectively. Documenting the outcomes of conflicts in lessons learned is good practice and helps in understanding what worked and what didn’t, providing valuable insights for future projects.


Not all conflicts are visible or known to others. Some conflicts may be subtle or unspoken, requiring the project manager to be observant and proactive in identifying and addressing them. A project manager should not wait to be asked to intervene in conflicts. Proactive conflict management is essential to prevent escalation and maintain a productive team environment. Finally, not all conflicts need to be escalated to the project sponsor. The project manager should handle conflicts at their level unless they are unable to resolve them or if the conflict has significant implications that require higher-level intervention.

choices.text: Conflict is a regular part of team culture.
Conflicts are always visible and known to others.
Intervene when requested.
Record outcomes of conflicts in lessons learned.
Escalate all conflicts to the project sponsor.

text:
A project manager has been assigned to a project to update an inventory process and cold storage equipment of an organization. The process owner, the purchasing department manager, and the warehouse manager are named key stakeholders on the project charter. The project manager has also received a copy of the business case from the business analyst.

Which two roles are responsible for planning the benefits for the project? (Choose 2)
explanation:
The project manager and business analyst are responsible for benefits planning. The project manager plans how the project can deliver the value and benefits identified by the business analyst in the business case. The responsibility of the business analyst is to align the project charter with the business case, which means benefit planning for the organization.

The other roles are responsible for fulfilling benefits or pursuing benefits realization.

choices.text: Project manager
Process owner
Purchasing department manager
Warehouse manager
Business analyst

text: Several exciting initiatives are happening throughout an agricultural product manufacturing company. Which statement describes a project ready for initiation?
explanation: The employee cafeteria and wellness center is the only project on this list. The project goal is to promote employee health, which includes a proposed scope of the new wellness center and menu options. Product roadmaps on their own are not enough to authorize a project without an identified business need and a supporting business case. The tractor assembly manager has identified a business need—in this case, a problem that should be resolved. The business case will check the feasibility and solution method before this can become a project. Finally, the hazardous waste material disposal cost may or may not be a problem. Perhaps this is the actual cost of the service or maybe the company wants to do something about it, but this statement on its own does not describe a project.

choices.text: A product owner has created a product roadmap for a second variety of the company’s popular seaweed-based fertilizer.
The functional manager supervising tractor assembly needs to improve speed while maintaining quality.
The cafeteria is being expanded to include a wellness center and healthier meal options to promote employee health.
Disposal of hazardous waste material cost the company US$3 million the previous year.

text:
A pharmaceutical company initiated a research project to develop a therapeutic solution. The project manager is carefully monitoring the work and project progress of the team. 

Which three project artifacts are important during this part of the project? (Choose 3)
explanation:
Change requests, project status reports, and work performance reports are critical during the monitoring and controlling phase of a project. Change requests document any modifications needed in the project scope, schedule, or resources based on the monitoring results. Project status reports provide a snapshot of the current state of the project, including progress, issues, and performance against the project management plan, which is essential for monitoring. Work performance reports compile data on project performance, including metrics and analyses, which are vital for assessing progress and making informed decisions.

The project charter is a document that formally authorizes the project and provides a high-level overview of its objectives, scope, and stakeholders. While the project charter is critical at the beginning of the project, it is not as relevant during the monitoring phase. The project manager needs more detailed and current information to track progress and performance. Lessons learned are valuable for capturing insights and knowledge gained from the project, which can be used to improve future projects. However, during the monitoring phase, the focus is on current project performance and progress. Lessons learned are typically documented and reviewed at the end of the project or at key milestones, rather than being a primary focus during ongoing monitoring.

choices.text: Change requests
Project status reports
Project charter
Work performance reports
Lessons learned

text: In which scenario is a predictive approach most suitable?
explanation:
The most suitable project for a predictive approach is the project type performed many times by the organization. Due to inexperience of the team, there may be certainty about project expectations that suits a plan-based approach. 
Innovative technology thrives in an adaptable environment where ideas can be tried and tested. If stakeholders have authorized a project they are not certain about, the team will need to provide proof of concept, which can best be accomplished using iterative development. If cost is a highly variable factor, this introduces uncertainty to the project as well.

choices.text: A project is using innovative technology.
Stakeholders are not certain about the need for the project.
The organization has performed this type of project many times.
Cost estimates are highly varied because of a changing market.

text: A project team has created a project management plan with scope, schedule, budget, risk, quality, and resource components. What should the project manager do next?
explanation:
After creating the individual components of the project management plan, the next step is to integrate these components into a cohesive and comprehensive project management plan. This ensures all aspects of the project are aligned and there is a clear, unified direction for the project.

Audits are typically conducted later in the project to ensure compliance and effectiveness, not after creating a project management plan. The Perform Integrated Change Control process is used to review and manage changes to the project. This process is applied after the project management plan is integrated and approved, not immediately after creating the plan components. Lessons learned typically are recorded throughout the project life cycle and especially during project closure, not immediately after creating the project management plan components.

choices.text: Audit the project management plan.
Integrate the plans.
Apply the Perform Integrated Change Control process.
Initiate lessons learned.

text: Which three options can be used to address uncertain risks or unexpected activities within the scope of work? (Choose 3)
explanation:
The contingency reserve is allocated for identified risks that are accepted and for which contingent or mitigating responses are developed. The contingency reserve is used to manage known-unknowns and is included in the cost baseline of the project. The management reserve is set aside for unforeseen work that is within the scope of the project. It is used to manage unknown-unknowns and is not included in the cost baseline of the project but is part of the overall project budget. Also known as slack, float is the amount of time that a task in a project network can be delayed without causing a delay to subsequent tasks or the project completion date. Float provides flexibility in the schedule to address unexpected activities.

Budget at completion (BAC) is the total budget allocated for the project and is not specifically used to address uncertain risks or unexpected activities but rather represents the overall planned expenditure. Earned value management (EVM) is a project management technique for measuring project performance and progress. While it helps in tracking and managing project performance, it is not a reserve or buffer used to address uncertain risks or unexpected activities.

choices.text: Budget at completion (BAC)
Contingency reserve
Management reserve
Earned value management (EVM
Float

text: A group comprising project stakeholders and organizational managers related to a project meet to approve a scope increase in a current project. What is this group called?
explanation:
The change control board (CCB) is a group of stakeholders and managers responsible for reviewing, evaluating, and approving or rejecting changes to the project scope, schedule, and cost. The CCB ensures any changes are thoroughly assessed for their impact on the project and align with the objectives and constraints of the project.

The project management office (PMO) provides support and governance for project management practices within an organization. While the PMO may be involved in the change control process, it is not the specific group responsible for approving scope changes. The steering committee is typically a high-level group that provides strategic direction and oversight for a project. While they may be involved in major decisions, the specific responsibility for approving scope changes typically lies with the CCB. The executive committee is a senior management group that oversees the overall strategic direction of the organization. The executive committee may be involved in high-level project decisions, but the detailed review and approval of scope changes are typically handled by the CCB.

choices.text: Project management office (PMO)
Steering committee
Change control board (CCB)
Executive committee

text: Which action should a project team take after a change request is rejected?
explanation:
When a change request is rejected, the project team should document this decision in the change log. The change log is a record of all change requests, their status, and the outcomes of the change control process. Updating the change log ensures there is a clear and traceable record of the decision, which is important for project documentation and future reference.

Changing the project baselines is not appropriate after a change request is rejected. The baselines should only be updated if a change request is approved and implemented. Escalating the request to the project sponsor is not necessary if the change request has already been reviewed and rejected through the proper change control process. The decision should be respected and documented. Implementing corrective action is not relevant in this context. Corrective actions are taken to address issues or deviations from the project management plan, not to respond to a rejected change request.

choices.text: Change the project baselines.
Escalate the request to the project sponsor.
Implement corrective action.
Update the change log.

text:
An established food manufacturing company authorizes a project to develop a new product line of healthy snacks. The project has many stakeholders, and the product should complete all required testing and be on the market within 18 months. Stakeholder input will be required on a continual basis to develop the right taste, look, and price point for the product. 

Which approach is best suited for this project?
explanation:
The correct answer is hybrid. The timeline requirement is the first clue. Projects with timelines work toward a defined end point. The company is established and experienced in the work of the project, so this adds an element of certainty to team member capability and ability to execute successfully. The risk or uncertainty in the project is related to the stakeholder input requirement. The product requirements are not defined and must be progressively elaborated or developed iteratively or incrementally. 

Adaptive is not the right approach for this project. Adaptive projects have defined initial baseline requirements but allow changes to occur during feedback due to uncertainties documented at project initiation. Predictive is incorrect, because the predictive approach establishes a well-defined baseline. Any feedback or changes would have to undergo the Perform Integrated Change Control process, which takes some time and effort. Incremental is also incorrect because it is only a partial answer that describes the product scope development aspect of the project.

choices.text: Adaptive
Hybrid
Predictive
Incremental

text:
A global company specializes in custom-designed swimwear. The company is very customer-oriented and launches a social media campaign seeking customer input on the perfect swimsuit. The designs for the following season will be chosen from customer input. 
Manufacturing must start in 60 days.  

Which project development approach should the project team use?
explanation:
An agile approach is well-suited for projects where customer feedback is crucial. This approach allows the team to iterate on designs based on customer input, ensuring the final product aligns with customer preferences. Given the 60-day timeline, the team can use short iterations to gather feedback and refine the designs quickly.
While a predictive approach can manage risks through detailed planning, it is less flexible in incorporating ongoing customer feedback, which is essential in this scenario.
In the case of an experienced agile project team using timeboxed iterations to create prototypes, this does not explicitly address the importance of customer feedback in guiding the team before manufacturing. The focus should be on the adaptive nature of the approach to incorporate feedback. Finally, since the manufacturing timeline is a 60-day constraint, the team should use a predictive approach with a controlled scope. This approach may not provide the flexibility needed to incorporate customer feedback effectively within the timeline.

choices.text: Because this is a high-risk project, the company should use a predictive approach.
An experienced agile project team can use several timeboxed iterations to create prototypes.
Since the manufacturing timeline is a 60-day constraint, the team should use a predictive approach with a controlled scope.
Incorporating customer feedback is essential to guide the team before manufacturing, so an adaptive approach is suitable.

text: A project team is reviewing a project charter for a new project to build a coffee press prototype. Which tool or technique should the team use?
explanation:
Brainstorming is a way of generating ideas and getting the team to think about how to start the project. In this case, the team can think and talk through ideas in a brainstorming session to build the best coffee press prototype. 

The three-point estimation technique is used for estimating the duration or cost of project activities by considering three scenarios (optimistic, pessimistic, and most likely). While useful for estimation, three-point estimation is not the initial step for starting work on a new project. Voting is a decision-making technique used to prioritize or select options based on team consensus and is not typically used as the initial step for starting work on a new project. A tornado diagram is a visual tool used in sensitivity analysis to identify the variables with the most significant impact on project outcomes. A tornado diagram is more relevant for risk analysis and decision-making rather than starting work on a new project.

choices.text: Three-point estimation
Voting
Brainstorming
Tornado diagram

text:
A project team is using an agile approach to equip a fleet of trucks using sustainable fuel technology. The project sponsor is aware of several scope changes and wants to know the current project scope. 

Which artifact can the project team and product owner use to satisfy the request of the project sponsor?
explanation:
As customer feedback is incorporated into an agile project, the changes are reflected in the product backlog. Any request for a change is evaluated by the product owner and project team, and a decision is made to implement it or not. The product backlog is the ordered list of all the work to be performed, so this will provide an updated vision of the project scope. 

A product roadmap provides a high-level overview of the goals and major milestones of the project over time. While useful for strategic planning, it does not provide the detailed and current scope information the product backlog offers. A burnup chart shows the amount of work completed versus the total amount of work over time. The burnup chart is useful for tracking progress but does not provide detailed scope information. A velocity chart tracks the amount of work completed in each iteration or sprint, helps in forecasting future work, but does not provide detailed scope information.

choices.text: Roadmap
Burnup chart
Velocity chart
Product backlog

text:
A project team is using the Kanban framework to develop a content portal. A backlog item is approved and placed on the iteration backlog.

What should the project team do next?
explanation:
After a backlog item is approved and published on the iteration backlog, it is available for the team to begin work. The project team pulls the following topic from the content backlog for writing. Kanban is based on a pull system.

The Kanban framework does not include periods of reflection for feedback and strategic adjustment. Regular stakeholder feedback meetings are not exclusive to Kanban, which emphasizes flow and continuity, not constant strategy reworks.

choices.text: Reflect on the feedback and adjust their content strategy.
Pull the following topic from the backlog for execution.
Schedule a meeting to discuss the feedback with stakeholders.
Prioritize upcoming backlog items.

text: What are three agile ceremonies or artifacts that enable communication, collaboration, and quality controls? (Choose 3)
explanation:
Daily coordination meetings are 10- to 15-minute meetings in which the team discusses any issues regarding the project, including impediments. The retrospective is an important review of the lessons learned and plan improvement actions. The backlog is where the project team and product owner collaborate and order work. These are the three ceremonies or artifacts that enable communication, collaboration, and quality controls. 

A product increment is a releasable amount of the final product, and the minimum viable product (MVP) can be considered a quality control in that it represents the threshold of acceptable quality for the final product. The MVP is a result of collaboration between the project team and product owner, but it does not facilitate communication.

choices.text: Backlog
Daily coordination meeting
Product increment
Retrospective
Minimum viable product (MVP)

text: At the end of a project, a client questions why a specific deliverable was included in the scope. Which business analysis tool should a project manager reference to explain to the client the purpose for that deliverable?
explanation:
The correct answer is the requirements traceability matrix, because a requirements traceability matrix links the product requirements from their origin to the deliverables that satisfy them. 

A prioritization matrix is used to prioritize project requirements or tasks based on certain criteria such as value, urgency, or impact. While it helps in decision-making, it does not provide a direct explanation of why a specific deliverable was included in the scope.
The situation statement outlines the problem or opportunity the project aims to address and is useful for understanding the context of the project but does not provide detailed traceability of specific deliverables. The product roadmap is a high-level visual summary that maps out the vision and direction of the product over time. While it provides an overview of the development of the product, it does not offer detailed traceability of individual deliverables.

choices.text: Requirements traceability matrix
Prioritization matrix
Situation statement
Product roadmap

text:
A business analyst has been struggling to assemble data for a business case for several months. Gathering detailed information has been challenging, because the stakeholders often provide generic company talking points, which is hindering progress of the business analyst. 

Which approach should the business analyst take to get the necessary detailed information?
explanation:
When a business analyst is struggling to gather detailed information for a business case due to stakeholders providing generic responses, the most effective approach is asking focused and open-ended questions until enough information is provided. This approach allows the business analyst to guide the conversation and delve deeper into specific areas. Focused questions help specify the topic, whereas open-ended questions encourage stakeholders to provide more detailed and comprehensive responses. This method is effective in extracting the necessary detailed information that generic talking points fail to provide.

While hiring an external facilitator might help in some situations, it may not be the most efficient or cost-effective solution. The facilitator may also face the same challenges in getting detailed information if stakeholders continue to provide generic responses. Interviewing people close to the stakeholders to obtain contextual information might provide some additional context but is indirect and may not yield the specific detailed information needed for the business case. This approach also risks misinterpretation or second-hand information that may not be accurate. Sending a digital survey to the stakeholders with a variety of questions can be useful for gathering broad information, but they may not be effective in obtaining detailed responses. Stakeholders might still provide generic answers, and the lack of immediate interaction makes it difficult to probe deeper into specific areas.

choices.text: Ask focused and open-ended questions until enough information is provided.
Hire an external facilitator to conduct information sessions.
Interview people close to the stakeholders to obtain contextual information.
Send a digital survey to the stakeholders with a variety of questions.

text:
A project team is working on a small project with only a few requirements. The team wants to show management how these requirements correspond to the project deliverables. 

Which tool should the team and business analyst use to show management how these requirements correspond to the project deliverables?
explanation:
In the scenario where a project team is working on a small project with only a few requirements and wants to show management how these requirements correspond to the project deliverables, the most appropriate tool to use is the requirements traceability matrix. This tool is specifically designed to map and trace the relationship between requirements and project deliverables. It ensures each requirement is linked to its corresponding deliverable, providing a clear and detailed view of how the project requirements are being met. This matrix helps in demonstrating to management the alignment between what is required and what is being delivered.

The responsibility assignment matrix is used to define and document the roles and responsibilities of team members for various project tasks and does not show the correspondence between requirements and deliverables. The milestone chart is used to track significant points or events in the project timeline. While it is useful for project scheduling and tracking progress, the milestone chart does not map requirements to deliverables.

The product roadmap is a high-level visual summary that outlines the vision, direction, and progress of a product over time. It provides an overview of product development but does not detail the correspondence between specific requirements and deliverables.

choices.text: Responsibility assignment matrix
Requirements traceability matrix
Milestone chart
Product roadmap

text: A business analyst is in the process of developing a product roadmap. Which planning component is a prerequisite in this process?
explanation:
In the scenario where a business analyst is developing a product roadmap, the most critical planning component that serves as a prerequisite is the product vision. The product vision is a high-level description of the purpose, goals, and value the product aims to deliver to customers. The product vision provides a clear direction and sets the foundation for all subsequent planning activities, including the development of the product roadmap. Without a well-defined product vision, it is challenging to create a coherent and aligned roadmap.

The release plan outlines the schedule for delivering product increments or releases. While important, the release plan is not a prerequisite for developing the product roadmap. The product roadmap should be based on the product vision and then inform the release plan. Identifying stakeholders is crucial for understanding who will be impacted by the product and who needs to be involved in the planning process. However, it is not a prerequisite for developing the product roadmap. The product vision should be established first to guide stakeholder engagement. A story map is a visual representation of the user stories of the product and their sequence and helps in organizing and prioritizing work but is not a prerequisite for the product roadmap. The product vision should guide the creation of the story map.

choices.text: Release plan
Identified stakeholders
Product vision
Story map

text: When does a business analyst perform the Conduct Elicitation process in a project with a timeboxed agile development approach?
explanation:
In an agile development approach, requirements elicitation is an ongoing process that occurs during each iteration. This process allows the team to continuously gather and refine requirements based on feedback and evolving project needs. Conducting elicitation during each iteration ensures the requirements are current, relevant, and aligned with the goals of the project.

While initial requirements elicitation may occur during the creation of the product backlog, it is not limited to this phase. Elicitation is a continuous process in agile projects. Agile projects typically do not follow a phase-based approach with distinct milestones. Instead, agile projects use iterations or sprints, making this option less relevant. And while the product owner may request updates, elicitation is a proactive and continuous process that occurs throughout each iteration, not just upon request.

choices.text: At initiation, while creating the initial product backlog
At each milestone, when a new phase starts
During each iteration
When the product owner requests an update

text: An agile project team working on a software development project has completed the coding tasks and now needs to validate the product requirements. Which of the following steps should the team take?
explanation:
The preferred course of action is to conduct user acceptance testing (UAT), which is a critical step in validating the product meets the requirements specified by the stakeholders. UAT is the process where the end users or stakeholders test the software to ensure it meets their requirements and works as expected in real-world scenarios. This step is crucial for validating the product requirements have been met and the software is ready for deployment.

Performing a benefits analysis involves evaluating the benefits of the project to ensure it delivers the expected value. While important, it is not directly related to validating the product requirements have been met. While verifying that all user stories are fulfilled is important, it is typically part of the development and review process. UAT is a more comprehensive step that involves actual users testing the software in real-world conditions. The requirements traceability matrix is a tool used to ensure all requirements are accounted for throughout the project life cycle. While useful for tracking requirements, the requirements traceability matrix does not involve actual validation of the product by end users.

choices.text: Perform a benefits analysis.
Verify all user stories are fulfilled.
Conduct user acceptance testing (UAT).
Consult the requirements traceability matrix.

text:
An agile project team has just started work developing a script for a video game. Team members are very excited about the work but argue all the time due to clashing working styles and creative approaches. 

What should the team lead do to ensure the project progresses smoothly?
explanation: In agile teams, addressing conflicts openly and collectively is crucial. Arranging a brainstorming session to establish team ground rules aligns with agile principles by involving the entire team in creating norms and expectations. This approach helps to address the current conflict and prevent future issues, fostering a collaborative and transparent team environment. Even though agile teams typically stay together and move from one initiative to another, unmanaged conflict can still disrupt the team. A dedicated brainstorming session is the most appropriate option because it aligns with principles and sets the team up for success and smooth progress.

choices.text: Ask the team to examine their working styles during the next retrospective.
Address the conflict quickly and in private, using a direct, collaborative approach.
Allow team members to resolve the conflict on their own without intervention.
Arrange a brainstorming session to discuss team ground rules.

text:
A project manager has recently left an organization with a formal and highly regulated culture. In an upcoming role, the project manager will lead a virtual team of aeronautical engineers and designers. During the engagement interview, the project manager was informed these engineers and designers are accustomed to a great deal of freedom in their working styles and little supervision. 

Which two actions should the project manager take to prepare for this transition? (Choose 2)
explanation:
The project manager should focus on understanding virtual team management practices and specific working styles of team members to ensure a smooth transition and effective leadership in the new role.

While considering the benefits of the agile mindset can be beneficial, this option is not as directly relevant to the immediate preparation for managing a virtual team with specific working style preferences. Scheduling a team kickoff meeting to update the continuous improvement plan is a good practice but not directly related to understanding and preparing for the team working styles and virtual team management. Consulting management theories about intrinsic and extrinsic motivations can be useful but is not as immediately practical as understanding virtual team practices and team working styles.

choices.text: Review good practices for virtual team working.
Become familiar with the typical working styles of people in the organization.
Consider the benefits of the agile mindset.
Schedule a team kickoff meeting to update their continuous improvement plan.
Consult management theories about intrinsic and extrinsic motivations.

text:
A project manager is tasked with building a team for the rollout of a new set of processes across a national franchise. In addition to three permanent cross-functional project team members, there is a budget to acquire more expertise. However, the project manager needs to determine the resource requirements first.

Which approach should the project manager consider?
explanation:
The project manager should perform a gap analysis to compare the current skills of the team members with the skills required for the rollout. The project manager should also examine the skills, knowledge, and abilities required by occupational groups, functions, and/or departments within the franchise. A gap analysis helps identify differences between the current skills of team members and the skills needed for the rollout, providing a clear roadmap for training and development. 

While stakeholder interviews can provide valuable insights, they may not offer a comprehensive or objective assessment of the specific skills and knowledge required. Stakeholders might have varying perspectives and may not be fully aware of the detailed requirements for the rollout. A project management training session is insufficient to ensure team members have the depth of knowledge and practical experience needed to teach new processes effectively. This assumption could lead to gaps in understanding and implementation. Finally, assessments focus on past performance in current roles and may not accurately reflect the specific skills and knowledge needed for the new processes. These assessments are typically retrospective and may not align with future requirements.

choices.text: Perform a gap analysis to compare the current skills of the team members with the skills required for the rollout.
Conduct interviews with stakeholders to identify the necessary skills and knowledge for the rollout.
Assume that team members who have attended a training session on project management are qualified to teach the new processes.
Conduct an assessment to evaluate how well team members have performed in their current roles.

text:
A development team is producing high-quality work and completing tasks quickly in a project to update an app using a new third-party technology. The product owner is highly optimistic, and the project manager is forecasting on-time release because of very positive stakeholder feedback. The company that developed the new technology, however, is in the news for securities fraud. Company leadership initiates a full security and ethics investigation following the troubling news.

What should the project manager do?
explanation: The preferred approach for the project manager is to collaborate with the product owner to determine the next step. This ensures both parties are aligned and can make an informed decision based on the impact of investigation on the project. Consulting the risk register is also a valuable action to understanding potential risks and mitigation strategies. Pausing development might lead to unnecessary delays. Working on nonfunctional requirements is a good interim solution but should be done in collaboration with the product owner to ensure alignment with project priorities.

choices.text: Pause development until leadership gives approval to proceed.
Consult the risk register.
Suggest the team work on nonfunctional requirements.
Collaborate with the product owner to determine the next step.

text:
A project manager has been named to lead a project to develop a solution. The project manager is eliciting requirements before finalizing the project charter. During interviews, the project manager determines the project sponsor and key stakeholders have differing expectations about timelines and quality. 

What should the project manager do to reconcile these differing expectations?
explanation:
In this scenario, the project manager is facing differing expectations from the project sponsor and key stakeholders regarding timelines and quality. It is crucial to reconcile these differences to ensure project success. Facilitating negotiations with the stakeholders about timelines and quality is the most appropriate approach because it involves direct communication and negotiation. Facilitating a negotiation allows the project manager to address concerns, find common ground, and reach a consensus on timelines and quality.

Deciding which stakeholder has the most power and influence, and considering that person the lead stakeholder, may lead to bias and does not address the root cause of differing expectations. It could also alienate other stakeholders, leading to further conflicts. While documenting and prioritizing requirements is important, this option does not directly address differing expectations about timelines and quality and focuses more on financial value rather than reconciling stakeholder differences. Finally, a Pareto analysis can help identify the most significant requirements but may not effectively reconcile differing expectations about timelines and quality and is more suited for identifying key issues rather than resolving conflicts.

choices.text: Conduct interviews to determine which party has the greatest power and influence and consider that person the lead stakeholder.
Collect and document all requirements, plot them on a requirements traceability matrix, then prioritize them according to financial value.
Conduct a Pareto analysis of all stakeholder requirements and present the results at a facilitated workshop.
Conduct a workshop with the stakeholders about timelines and quality.

text:
An airport authority authorizes a project to review arrival and departure schedules at a small airport. During preliminary engagements with stakeholders, the project manager learns they want to prioritize cargo planes, then sell the remaining slots using a transparent process. 

Which action should the project manager take next?
explanation: This project manager has been assigned to a project and is authorized to begin work, so it is time to create a project management plan. A bidder conference is a meeting held with prospective sellers prior to the preparation of a bid or proposal. The primary purpose of this conference is to ensure all prospective vendors have a clear and common understanding of the procurement requirements. We use a request for proposal (RFP) when we need to solicit proposals from potential vendors or service providers for a project where the solution is not straightforward and requires detailed proposals. A configuration management plan is created to ensure all project artifacts are identified, tracked, and controlled throughout the project life cycle.

choices.text: Schedule a bidder conference.
Publish a request for proposal (RFP).
Develop a project management plan.
Create a configuration management plan.

text:
Three months into a project, a project team member alerts the project manager to an incident involving one of the vendors using equipment that belongs to the project. The project manager investigates and discovers the vendor has a long-standing relationship with the project sponsor.

Which two actions should the project manager take? (Choose 2)
explanation:
The project manager should take actions that ensure proper investigation and documentation of the incident. Contacting the procurement and legal departments helps in understanding the contractual and legal implications, whereas logging the issue and examining the incident ensure the incident is properly tracked and investigated. These actions provide a comprehensive approach to addressing the issue while maintaining transparency and compliance with organizational policies. 

Asking the project sponsor if they allowed the vendor to use the equipment and escalating to the project management office (PMO) may be considered after the initial investigation if further clarification or action is needed. Allowing work to continue without addressing the issue is not advisable.

choices.text: Contact the procurement and legal departments to review the vendor contract for conflict-of-interest disclosure.
Ask the project sponsor if they allowed the vendor to use the equipment.
Log the issue in the issue log and examine the reported incident with the vendor and team member.
Allow work to continue because the equipment was already used.
Escalate the issue to the project management office (PMO) immediately.

text:
During a product review meeting, project team members argue about who was supposed to update test results from the previous week. To encourage the team to become more familiar with project management, the project manager advises team members to find the answer in a specific document.

Which document is the project manager referring to?
explanation:
The RACI (responsible, accountable, consulted, informed) matrix is the correct document because it explicitly outlines who is responsible for specific tasks such as updating test results. This document helps clarify roles and responsibilities, reducing confusion and ensuring accountability within the project team.

The project management plan is a comprehensive document that outlines how the project will be executed, monitored, and controlled. While this document includes various subsidiary plans, it does not specifically detail individual responsibilities for tasks such as updating test results. The requirements traceability matrix links requirements to their origins and tracks them throughout the project life cycle. This document ensures all requirements are addressed but does not specify who is responsible for updating test results. The quality management plan outlines the quality policies, procedures, and criteria for the project. This document includes information on quality assurance and control but does not detail individual task responsibilities.

choices.text: Project management plan
Requirements traceability matrix
Quality management plan
RACI (responsible, accountable, consulted, informed) matrix

text:
A company is in a country where the inflation rate has soared over the last decade. Most of the projects of this company are conducted in this country. 
 
Which three options should the project manager consider when forming a comprehensive approach to managing future projects? (Choose 3)
explanation:
When planning future projects in a country with a high inflation rate, the project manager should consider strategies to mitigate the financial risks associated with inflation. Using a fixed-price-with-economic-price-adjustment contract to protect the project from budget increases attached to specific costs is an effective strategy for managing the impact of high inflation on project budgets. This contract provides a mechanism to adjust prices in response to economic changes, thereby protecting the project from budget overruns due to inflation. Combining this approach with regular updates to the procurement management plan and risk register and maintaining strong relationships with the finance and procurement teams provides a comprehensive approach to managing inflation-related risks.

Using a high-risk threshold in planning may help manage unexpected costs due to inflation but may not be the most efficient or proactive strategy because it focuses on reacting to risks rather than preventing them. While adding a contingency reserve can help manage risks, it may not be sufficient to address the specific issue of inflation, which can significantly impact project costs over time. Reducing the project scope might help in controlling costs but does not directly address the issue of inflation and its impact on project budgets.

choices.text: Plan the project with a high-risk threshold and add a high contingency reserve.
Use a fixed-price-with-economic-price-adjustment contract to protect the project from budget increases.
Update the procurement management plan and risk register regularly.
Create close working relationships with the finance and procurement teams to ensure adequate governance.
Focus on reducing project scope to control or minimize cost

text:
In a large organization, a project manager is leading a strategic project that is critical to success of the organization and is experiencing a delay related to unresponsive stakeholders and outstanding sign-offs on reports. While reviewing the lessons learned repository, the project manager notices inconsistencies in project documentation and reporting standards across different projects. 

What should the project manager do first?
explanation:
The preferred course of action is to collaborate with the project management office (PMO) to ensure standardized documentation and reporting guidelines are available and followed across all projects. This approach addresses the inconsistencies and helps in maintaining a uniform standard, which is critical for successful projects in this organization.

Continuing with the current documentation and reporting standards without addressing the inconsistencies will not resolve the underlying issue. It assumes that other projects will follow, which is not guaranteed and may lead to additional inconsistencies. Developing a set of documentation and reporting standards and implementing them within the strategic project is a proactive approach. However, this approach does not address the need for organization-wide consistency and may lead to additional discrepancies if not aligned with the standards of the PMO. Focusing solely on completing the strategic project on time and escalating the inconsistencies to the PMO addresses the immediate project needs. This approach, however, does not proactively resolve the documentation and reporting standards issue and may lead to temporary fixes rather than a long-term solution.

choices.text: Continue using the current documentation and reporting standards for the strategic project and assume other projects will follow.
Develop a set of documentation and reporting standards and implement them within the strategic project.
Collaborate with the project management office (PMO) to verify standardized documentation and reporting guidelines are available for all projects.
Focus on completing the strategic project on time and escalate the inconsistencies to the project management office (PMO).

text:
A high-profile project to launch a global event is nearly complete, but the team has been experiencing significant stress for the last few weeks while working on-site and away from the office. Ahead of the final on-site visit, the project manager has heard reports of team members crying, arguing, and working very late into the night. During the airplane journey, the project manager reviews the latest project status, confirming all milestones have been met and the project is on track. Arriving on-site, the project manager notices the team seems to be working normally.

How should the project manager approach this situation?
explanation:
Under the circumstances, it seems logical the team would be experiencing stress. Late nights and emotional behavior can be normal under stressful conditions. The project manager should use emotional intelligence (EI) and meet with the team to understand what has been happening. This approach will allow the project manager to gather accurate information, address team concerns, and take appropriate actions to resolve any conflicts and reduce stress. 

Organizing time off for the team at the first available opportunity might be beneficial but does not address the underlying issues causing stress and conflict. Observing and assessing the situation using a quality checklist might help in assessing the work but does not address the emotional and interpersonal issues the team is facing. Finally, preparing to resolve team conflicts ahead of the project launch is important, but the project manager should first understand the specific issues by meeting with the team.

choices.text: Organize time off for the team at the first available opportunity.
Meet with the team to find out what has really been happening.
Observe and assess the situation using a quality checklist.
Prepare to resolve team conflicts ahead of the project launch.

text:
Work on a civil engineering project has stopped temporarily because of soaring temperatures. Climate change is affecting workers and infrastructure stability, posing significant risks to continuing the project. 

Which two actions should the project manager take to address these challenges? (Choose 2)
explanation:
Climate change impacts require short- and long-term solutions. Pivoting to a more flexible way of working that includes contingency measures for climate-related risks is a good short-term solution.
